title: magnus carlsen v fabiano caruana world chess championship game 8 live
story: Eight straight draws and a 4-all deadlock. Will Wednesday finally be the day for a decisive result? Weâ€™ll soon find out. Be sure to join us then for more minute-by-minute coverage.Weâ€™re inching closer to a potential tie-breaker, where Carlsen will be a considerable favorite in a series of matches under shorter time controls. After all the Norwegian is the worldâ€™s No 1 rapid player and No 1 blitz player (compared to Caruanaâ€™s respective ratings of No 8 and No 16). Heâ€™s also got experience on the stage having retained the title in the tie-break stage against Sergey Karjakin two years ago in New York. But he believes thereâ€™s plenty of road to go when asked about it. â€œFor you Fabiano, does it feel like missing a penalty or was it (not) that bad?â€ asks a reporter regarding the mental aftereffects of a game like Mondayâ€™s. The American responds: â€œI donâ€™t think the position was ever quite like that. I had some chances, itâ€™s not like itâ€™s always going to work out. Just because you put some pressure on Magnus doesnâ€™t mean that he collapses or anything. I had some chances. I donâ€™t know how serious they were. It definitely wasnâ€™t like missing a penalty.â€Says the moderator, English grandmaster Daniel King: â€œMind you, youâ€™re in England. We miss penalties very easily.â€â€œSome minor disappointment,â€ Caruana says when asked to assess his emotions after the match. â€œI thought at some point I had a very promising position. I didnâ€™t quite see exactly which moment I had something very good.â€Says a relieved Carlsen: â€œThis was a tough game. He was the one who had all the chances. So I am happy to have survived it for sure.â€Caruana plays 35. Rf6 and heâ€™s down to 15 minutes. Carlsen answers with 35. ... Re2 and heâ€™s under 10 minutes. Another back-and-forth (36. Rg6+ Kf8) and hereâ€™s what weâ€™re looking at. The position appears to be a simple draw after 32. ... Kf7 33. Bxh4 Re8. But Caruana grinds on, putting Carlsen in check with 34. Rf1+ followed by 34. ... Kg8. Caruana in right mind to keep pushing even if a draw seems inevitable with only two more games as white. Also, one could cargue consented to a peaceful result perhaps too soon in Game 2 when he could have made Carlsen work for it for at least a few more hours. Black is the one who needs to be more accurate in the current position and Carlsen has about twice as much time as Carlsen, who is down to 11 minutes.Further simplification as the players trade rooks: 31. Rf6 Rxf6 32. Bxf6. The computer is tipping a very slight (+0.34) advantage to Caruana for bringing his bishop into that critical square, but an impending second rook exchange should put this one to bed.Quick back-and-forth with 30. Re1 Bg4. Carlsen has everything under control. The time situation is practically even with both players around 22 minutes for their next nine moves until the time control.Caruana opted for simplification with 27. h4. Carlsen, after a 10-minute think, accepts the pawn with 27. ... gxh4. We appear bound for a draw after Caruana takes a pawn back (28. Qxf4) and the players exchange queens (28. ... Qxf4 29. Rxf4) followed by 29. ... h5. Weâ€™re just over three hours in todayâ€™s game but getting the sense it might not last much longer. It appears weâ€™re headed for a draw after 25. Nc4 Qg6 26. Nxd6 Qxd6. Caruana comes back with 27. h4, indicating heâ€™s not completely given up hopes for a win. Alas, as grandmaster Susan Polgar assesses, an eighth straight peaceful appears in the offing.And Caruana has played 21. c5 after 34 minutes. Itâ€™s a pawn sacrifice though not an immediate one. Carlsen, needing to speed up due to the mounting time crunch, quickly takes whiteâ€™s bishop on f3 and Caruana takes the bishop with his queen (21. ... Nxf3+ 22. Qxf3). Now Carlsen takes the pawn (22. ... dxc5) and Caruana responds with 23. Rad1. This is the critical moment of the game and match, perhaps as golden an opportunity as Caruana will get to stake a lead. The Norwegian supercomputer Sesse, running Stockfish, now giving the American a big advantage. But can Caruana find all the right moves?Caruana indeed finds 20. Bc3, and Carlsen goes in the tank again before answering with 20 ... Bf5. He spent 20min 53sec on that response and is now almost 50 minutes behind on time. That gives him 34 minutes to makes his next 20 moves. The engines love 21. c5 for Caruana. If he can find it, the advantage will tip even further in the Americanâ€™s favor. Carlsen responds with 19. ... f4. Caruana faces an important decision. The Norwegian supercomputer Sesse already gives the American an advantage and indicates he can push it with Bc3. Can Fabi find it and turn the screw?Carlsen plays 18. ... g5 and the fight is on! A audacious, aggressive move, especially when heâ€™s so far behind on time. But this is Game 8 and, not unlike the match against Karjakin two years ago in New York, Carlsen is going all in. The engines indicate Caruana needs to find 19. c4 and the American manages to find it in less than four minutes!Another sequence of moves ending with a pawn exchange: 15. Nc4 Ne5 16. Nb6 Rb8 17. f4 exf3 18. Bxf3. Caruana, moving with incredible pace, has more time than he started with thanks to the 30 seconds added to his clock with each move. And now Carlsen is in the tank. Five minutes. Ten minutes. Carlsen weighs his options, at times a bit more fidgety than weâ€™re used to seeing him as Caruana takes a long break from the board. He knows just how crucial this move could prove given Caruanaâ€™s razor-sharp preparation. Carlsen already a half hour behind on the clock. And we wait ...Carlsen responds to Caruanaâ€™s 14. Na3 with 14. ... e4. The champion is a bit out of his element with this opening: heâ€™s spent about 24 minutes on his last four moves. Says Russian grandmaster Peter Svidler: â€œThis is by far the liveliest opening position weâ€™ve had since Game 1.â€Carlsen takes nine minutes before responding with 12. ... f5. Caruana quickly responds with 13. a5 and Carlsen takes another six minutes before coming back with 13. ... a6. Some exciting potential here.We have our first surprise with 12. Bd2. This comes on the heels of 9. a4 (where c4 is far more common), followed by 9. ... Be7 10. Be2 O-O 11. O-O Nd7. Theyâ€™re making a lot of moves very quickly. Weâ€™ll catch up when they pause for their first thing. Hereâ€™s what theyâ€™re looking at after: 5. Nc3 e5 6. Ndb5 d6 7. Nd5 Nxd5 8. exd5 Nb8 9. a4.And weâ€™re off with 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4. For the fourth time we have the Sicilian and itâ€™s not the Rossolimo. And with 4. ... Nf6 5. Nc3 e5, weâ€™re into the Sveshnikov variation. Hello and welcome to London for todayâ€™s eighth game of the world chess championship between Norwayâ€™s Magnus Carlsen and Fabiano Caruana of the United States. Play resumes today after with the best-of-12-games match deadlocked at 3Â½-all following seven consecutive peaceful results.Carlsen, 27, has been ranked No 1 for eight straight years and was considered the worldâ€™s best player even before he defeated Viswanathan Anand for the title in 2013. Caruana, 26, is ranked No 2, having earned his place at the table by winning the candidates tournament in March. No American-born player has won or even competed for the world title since Bobby Fischer in 1972.&nbspIt marks the first title match between the world's top two players since 1990, when Garry Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov faced off for a fifth and final time.&nbspThe match will consist of 12 classical games with each player awarded one point for a win and a half-point for a draw. Whoever reaches six and a half points first will be declared the champion.The time control for each game is 100 minutes for the first 40 moves, 50 minutes for the next 20 moves and then 15 minutes for the rest of the game plus an additional 30 seconds per move starting from move 1. Players cannot agree to a draw before Black's 30th move.&nbspIf the match is tied after 12 games, tie-breaks will be played on the final day in the following order:&nbsp&nbspâ€¢ Best of four rapid games with 25 minutes for each player with an increment of 10 seconds after each move.&nbsp&nbspâ€¢ If still tied, they will play up to five mini-matches of two blitz games (five minutes for each player with a three-second increment).&nbspâ€¢ If all five mini-matches are drawn, one sudden-death 'Armegeddon' match will be played where White receives five minutes and Black receives four minutes. Both players will receive a three-second increment after the 60th move. In the case of a draw, Black will be declared the winner.Thu 8 Nov â€“ Opening ceremony Fri 9 Nov â€“ Game 1&nbspSat 10 Nov â€“ Game 2 Sun 11 Nov â€“ Rest day Mon 12 Nov â€“ Game 3 Tue 13 Nov â€“ Game 4 Wed 14 Nov â€“ Rest day Thu 15 Nov â€“ Game 5 Fri 16 Nov â€“ Game 6 Sat 17 Nov â€“ Rest day Sun 18 Nov â€“ Game 7 Mon 19 Nov â€“&nbspGame 8 Tue 20 Nov â€“&nbspRest day Wed 21 Nov â€“ Game 9 Thu 22 Nov â€“&nbspGame 10 Fri 23 Nov â€“&nbspRest day Sat 24 Nov â€“ Game 11 Sun 25 Nov â€“ Rest day Mon 26 Nov â€“ Game 12 Tue 27 Nov â€“ Rest day Wed 28 Nov â€“ Tie-break gamesAwards and closingThe games commence each day at 3pm in London.A brief recap if youâ€™re just parachuting in: Game 1 was a grueling seven-hour, 115-move draw, where Carlsen nearly become the first defending champion to win the opening game of a world title match with the black pieces in 37 years. The next four â€“ last Saturdayâ€™s Game 2, Mondayâ€™s Game 3 and Tuesdayâ€™s Game 4 and Thursdayâ€™s Game 5 â€“ were mostly safer, conservative affairs. Then came Fridayâ€™s Game 6, where Carlsen was outplayed by Caruana in the middlegame and pushed to the limit before saving a draw with incredibly precise defending under pressure. They played to another draw in yesterdayâ€™s Game 7, one that left a somewhat downtrodden Carlsen lamenting his gun-shy play and missed chances to be more aggressive in the aftermath.This is Carlsenâ€™s second consecutive world title defense thatâ€™s opened with seven straight draws. The 2016 match with Russiaâ€™s Sergey Karjakin unfolded the same way until Carlsenâ€™s gamble for a win with white in the eighth game backfired and he was made to resign under time pressure, only to hit back with a six-and-a-half-hour grind on Thanksgiving Day that forced the tie-breaker where he retained his title for a second time.Will we finally get a decisive result today? Weâ€™ll soon find out with Game 8 kicking off at the top of the hour.Bryan will be here shortly. In the meantime hereâ€™s his report from Sundayâ€™s seventh game, which left a somewhat downtrodden Carlsen lamenting his missed opportunities to be more aggressive.

title: super duper close up review yard theatre
story: The Yard, LondonThe latest from theatre company Made in China is an arresting monologue about an actor prone to panic attacks and phone addictionA woman in a frilly green dress stands centre stage, flanked by sparkly silver curtains. She looks girly but exhausted, stuck between childhood and maturity. The stage is equally in limbo. A projection screen hangs above a bright picture of a waterfall and odd props â€“ flowers, clothes, make-up â€“ lie strewn about. It looks like a film set a funeral parlour a karaoke bar a luxury holiday. This is a set that doesnâ€™t know itself, designed with an easy sense of chaos by Emma Bailey. It is the ideal backdrop for a show about an anxious actress at a crossroads, unsure of where to go next.Made in Chinaâ€™s shows always feel personal but this one, conceived by the company, feels particularly honest. Jessica Latowicki performs a monologue about an experimental actor recently prone to panic attacks. The narrative focuses on an imminent important meeting with an agent, but it gradually unspools. It is a restless piece, which picks and pecks at themes such as anxiety, self-image, the tension between creativity and stability, and the searing intensity of self-doubt.The companyâ€™s previous shows have been a lot more physical, infused with manic dancing, screwball comedy or visual gags. Super Duper Close Up is calmer by comparison and can sometimes feel a little flat. But despite the dips in energy, there is an arresting rhythm to the writing. The script is jittery and not quite in control of itself, and is repeatedly punctuated by Google searches and obsessive references to various friendsâ€™ glowing Facebook updates. As Latowicki speaks, she mimes scrolling through her phone. Itâ€™s as if the internet has become the chief driving force: the brain that now controls Jessicaâ€™s actions, feelings and fate.

title: airbnb removes rentals in israeli west bank settlements
story: Announcement comes before publication of damning Human Rights Watch reportAirbnb has said it will remove from its website all properties in Israeli settlements built on the occupied Palestinian territories in the West Bank, after years of accusations that the company was benefitting from rentals in the illegal outposts.The accommodation bookings website announced on Monday that around 200 listings would be taken down in what will be seen as a victory for the Palestinian-led anti-occupation movement.â€œMany in the global community have stated that companies should not do business here because they believe companies should not profit on lands where people have been displaced,â€ it said in a statement posted on its website.â€œWe concluded that we should remove listings in Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank that are at the core of the dispute between Israelis and Palestinians.â€The announcement came before the publication on Tuesday of a damning report by the New York-based advocacy group Human Rights Watch on the negative implications of its settlement business.Airbnb, which says it operates in 191 countries, will face a backlash from within Israel and from its international backers, who have fiercely fought attempts to delegitimise Israelâ€™s control of the West Bank.Israelâ€™s tourism minister Yariv Levin called the decision â€œdiscriminatoryâ€, according to Israeli media, and instructed his ministry to â€œlimit the companyâ€™s activity throughout the countryâ€. It was not clear what this would mean.Israel captured the West Bank from Jordanian forces in 1967 and continues to control and occupy the area, although Palestinians have limited self-rule over small enclaves.Ideologically driven Jewish nationalists who claim all of historic Palestine have since created outposts there, pushing out Palestinian residents. Today, more than half a million settlers live in what have become sprawling towns connected by a network of roads that cut up the West Bank.Settlements have long been seen as a critical barrier to a peace deal, which the international community broadly agrees should be two states side by side, one for Israelis and one for Palestinians.Activists have for years called for Airbnb and other companies to withdraw from the disputed territory, and Airbnb acknowledged it had â€œstruggled to come up with the right approachâ€.Human Rights Watch welcomed the move. Arvind Ganesan, the business and human rights director at the organisation, said Airbnbâ€™s decision was â€œan important recognition that such listings canâ€™t square with its human rights responsibilitiesâ€.â€œFor two years, Human Rights Watch has spoken with Airbnb about their brokering of rentals in West Bank settlements that are illegal under international humanitarian law and for which Palestinian ID holders are effectively barred from entering,â€ he said.The settlement movement has sought to encourage tourism in occupied land, with the help of the Israeli government, which established national parks there. A leaked European Union report said some projects were being used â€œas a political tool to â€¦ support, legitimise and expand settlementsâ€.In 2016, Airbnb came under added scrutiny after it was revealed that its website listed settlement properties as being inside the state of Israel, and not the Palestinian territories.Husam Zomlot, a Palestinian diplomat, condemned the firm at the time, saying it was â€œpromoting stolen property and land. There will come a time when companies like this, who profit from the occupation, will be taken to court.â€On Monday, a senior Palestinian negotiator, Saeb Erekat, described Airbnbâ€™s decision as an â€œinitial positive stepâ€ but complained that it did not include East Jerusalem, which was also captured and occupied in the 1967 war.

title: top filmmakers back penguin intervention on attenborough show
story: Wildlife documentary experts defend crewâ€™s decision to help trapped birdsLeading wildlife camera operators and film-makers have defended the film crew on David Attenboroughâ€™s latest BBC series over their decision to break with convention and intervene to save a group of penguins that had become trapped in a ravine.Nature film-makers are discouraged from intervening in the events they are attempting to capture on film. While the general principle is to avoid interfering with the natural course of events, the crew on the Dynasties series stepped in when they saw the birdsâ€™ predicament.The penguins at the centre of Sundayâ€™s episode of Dynasties had either blown or tumbled into a gully in a storm and were unable to to get out. In what BBC Earth described as an â€œunprecedented moveâ€, the crew dug a shallow ramp so some of the penguins would be able to use it to save themselves.But Allan said he saw no problem with the film crewâ€™s intervention. â€œInterfering or not is a decision based on what youâ€™re seeing at the time. To interfere on a predation event is definitely wrong but, in this situation, they didnâ€™t spook the penguins. All they did was create an escape route for them,â€ he said. Allan explained it would have been a far more stressful situation for the penguins had the film crew decided to pick them up and move them.He added: â€œI certainly think, in that case, what they did was entirely justifiable and entirely understandable. I would have done the same thing in their situation.â€Philip Hoare, author and film-maker, said the crew were bound to upset someone whichever way they responded. He said he found himself in a similar position when he was in Sri Lanka filming sperm whales. When a group of killer whales appeared to hunt the sperm whales, he realised his boat was in between the predator and prey. â€œIt was a very difficult thing to make a decision on,â€ he said, â€œI didnâ€™t want to see any whales die, but there was a possibility that, by being there, we were frustrating one speciesâ€™ natural instinct and need.â€ In that instance, his crew moved the boat.He added that it was impossible to document an encounter between a human and another species objectively. â€œThis notion of purity of an encounter between a human and another species is absolutely ridiculous. Thereâ€™s no possibility of that.â€Mike Gunton, the executive producer of the series, also defended the crewâ€™s decision to help the penguins. He told Radio 4â€™s Today programme: â€œIn the 30 years Iâ€™ve been doing this, itâ€™s one of the very few occasions when weâ€™ve ever done anything like this because itâ€™s a very unusual situation. Normally, you donâ€™t interfere, you canâ€™t interfere, or you wouldnâ€™t interfere because of all sorts of consequences.â€œOne, it would be very dangerous to do often for both you and the animal. Also, youâ€™ll probably be changing the dynamics of the natural system or you might be depriving something of its food. But, in this particular situation, none of those things applied.â€While it has previously been reported that Attenborough had opposed the move, saying that â€œtragedy is a part of lifeâ€, Gunton said that the presenter had told him he also would have rescued the penguins.

title: north may serve as post brexit bridge to eu claims retail ni
story: Since British prime minister Theresa May revealed details of the UKâ€™s orce deal, there has been  growing support from business groups in Northern Ireland.Northern Ireland could be the â€œbridge to the European Union and have the best of both worldsâ€ after the UK leaves the EU, according to a leading retail organisation which has become the latest business body in the North to back the UKâ€™s draft Brexit agreement.Retail NI, which represents 1,300 independent businesses, confirmed on Monday that while it did not believe the draft deal was â€œperfectâ€ it had decided to support it because of the potential â€œeconomic disaster of no dealâ€.Glyn Roberts, chief executive of Retail NI, said: â€œIf this deal is not voted through the House of Commons then we face the chaos of the UK crashing out of the EU. We are satisfied that it gives protection to the vital retail supply chain and ensures businesses will have full and tariff-free access to the UK and EU single markets.â€Mr Roberts has called for political leaders to put the Northâ€™s â€œeconomy, future prosperity and peopleâ€™s jobsâ€ before their own respective political beliefs.Since British prime minister Theresa May revealed details of the UKâ€™s orce deal last week, there has been a growing groundswell of support for it from businesses groups in Northern Ireland.Among the first to back the proposed deal were four of the Northâ€™s largest business groups which collectively said the agreement, while â€œby no means perfectâ€ was a â€œwelcome step forwardâ€.The Confederation of British Industry NI, the Institute of Directors NI, the Federation of Small Businesses and the Northern Ireland Chamber of Commerce have all agreed that the draft Brexit agreement provides local firms in the North with some clarity and will enable all the parties involved in the negotiations to â€œmove on to the critical next stageâ€.The Northâ€™s Livestock and Meat Commission has also welcomed the withdrawal agreement because it believes â€œa no-deal scenario would be a devastating blow to the Northern Ireland red meat industryâ€, while the Northern Ireland Food and Drink Association and the Ulster Farmerâ€™s Union have also both acknowledged that Theresa Mayâ€™s hard-fought plan could help avoid the one scenario which they both dread â€“ a no-deal Brexit.Leading industry groups including the Northern Ireland Retail Consortium, Manufacturing NI, Hospitality Ulster, Freight Transport Association Northern Ireland and the Northern Ireland Meat Exportersâ€™ Association have all described the draft agreement as a â€œwelcome stepâ€ towards a deal. While the Anglo-North Irish Fish Producersâ€™ Organisation has said it also views it as an â€œextremely important first stepâ€.

title: deal versus no deal a false choice arlene foster claims
story: Northern secretary Karen Bradley: told business leaders the draft deal was no  threat to Northâ€™s union with Britain. Photograph:  Colm LenaghanPacemaker PressDUP leader Arlene Foster has accused the British and Irish governments of creating a â€œa false choiceâ€ between accepting the draft withdrawal agreement or having no deal.Ms Foster said on Monday that the Brexit deal would lock the United Kingdom into the European Union â€œwith no way outâ€.â€œWe have been told that the backstop is only necessary to prevent such a hard border, but these comments make it clear that the EUâ€™s insistence on a backstop was not aimed at this,â€ she said. â€œThe European Unionâ€™s focus on the Border between Northern Ireland and the Republic has only ever been a negotiating tactic to secure its own aims in the negotiations.â€The DUP has come under pressure from business groups in the North to support the agreement but Ms Foster said: â€œI appreciate the concerns people have about a no deal but this should not be a binary choice. It is absolutely clear that it is time to work for a better deal.â€œThe agreement that has been put on the table is clearly not a good deal and no one should be forced into accepting another false choice.â€Sinn FÃ©in leader Mary Lou McDonald said on Monday the DUP was â€œcatastrophically wrongâ€ in rejecting the withdrawal agreement.â€œItâ€™s now very clear right across Ireland, North and South, that key voices from business, agriculture and other sectors are coming out and facing down the very negative politics advanced by the DUP and the Tory Brexiteers, â€ said Ms McDonald.Earlier, northern secretary Karen Bradley urged her fellow MPs to â€œput the national interest firstâ€ and sign up to the draft Brexit deal.She also suggested that failure to accept the deal would result in a hard border between the North and the South. If World Trade Organisation rules applied in the event of no deal then there would have to be border checks, she told a conference of more than 70 leading Northern Ireland business people on Monday.As the DUP continued to warn that the draft deal was a threat to Northern Irelandâ€™s union with Britain, Ms Bradley told business leaders no such threat existed.â€œThe agreement preserves the economic and constitutional integrity of the United Kingdom, upholds the Belfast Agreement, and ensures people and businesses that rely on an open border between Northern Ireland and Ireland can continue living their lives and operating as they do now,â€ she said in her speech.Ms Bradley, when speaking at the Belfast Met College in the cityâ€™s Titanic Quarter, made no direct reference to the DUP â€“ â€œI am not singling any party out,â€ she said â€“ but insisted that â€œcompromises have to be made, accommodations have to be madeâ€.Several speakers disputed claims by senior DUP politicians that business leaders did not understand the constitutional threat inherent in the deal.Angela McGowan, director of Confederation of British Industry NI, said: â€œMy members donâ€™t see this as any threat to their Britishness or their nationalities, and donâ€™t see it as a threat to the constitution.â€Trevor Lockhart, chairman of CBI NI said: â€œNothing in the deal undermines the constitutional integrity of the United Kingdom.â€ Tina McKenzie, head of the Northâ€™s Federation of Small Business said Northern Ireland could not afford the disruption of a no deal: â€œWe are fully aware of what a hard Brexit would do to our economy.â€

title: miriam lord varadkar s speech was like a hobbit s front door very low key
story: An Taoiseach Leo Varadkar  addresses the delegates. Photograph: Nick BradshawThrilled delegates knew they were in for a white-knuckle ride when Simon Coveney almost fist-bumped Regina Doherty onstage and then gingerly punched the air before inciting the Fine Gael mob to act like hooligans.The headline act was about to explode upon their ardfheis and the Tearaway TÃ¡naiste wanted the crowd to make some noise.â€œIn six minutesâ€™ time,â€ he tantalised, â€œour party leader and our Taoiseach will walk to this stage.â€Leo taking himself forward, in tune with the theme of the day.The country would be watching.â€œI know that this party has a reputation for being polite and mannerly and a little contained sometimes at events like this one,â€ devil-may-care Coveney told the crowd. â€œBut not today, please! I am asking you to make a statement, to be heard, to let people know how united and strong we are as a political party right now behind Leo Varadkar.â€There was a brief, polite pause and then the inflamed foot soldiers burst into a frenzy of genteel clapping. Guests in the diplomatic seating area were worried in case the rabble-rousing Minister for Foreign Affairs might start wrecking the gaff. But Simon settled down and there was no need to call security.Due to upstaging issues, seconds in command donâ€™t often do the wind-up speech for party leaders. They are too far up the pecking order, too close to the crown. Somebody who wonâ€™t thieve some shine from the star â€“ usually an up-and-coming candidate or a knockabout crowd favourite â€“ is chosen.On Saturday night, the former rivals for the countryâ€™s top job stood together, recast as Irelandâ€™s Brexit warriors.â€œWe work together night and day to protect Ireland,â€ Coveney declared, just in time for the live TV broadcast and the showcasing of the wonderful Two Ts to a national audience.A wide black curtain was pulled back to allow Leo make his entrance from the back of the hall. They had to do this because after Simonâ€™s podium paean (tough, calm, intelligent, educated, ambitious, compassionate, generous, change maker), Leo couldnâ€™t fit his head though the double doors.He got a tremendous reception as he did some minor flesh pressing on his way to the stage, the Kongos song â€œCome With Me Nowâ€ pulsating from the sound system.â€œWoah come with me nowIâ€™m gonna take you downWoah come with me nowIâ€™m gonna show you howâ€As you do.Some bright spark put a joke early on in the script. It involved using one of the props â€“ â€œordinaryâ€ party members sitting woodenly in long rows behind the Taoiseach who had, apparently, asked him questions earlier which he would address in the speech. This was a way of getting over the makey-up â€œI met a man out along the road who told me . . .â€These people had names, and when Leo mentioned them he swivelled his head towards the props to indicate that Tom or Lynda or Vera or whoever actually existed, and was there among them.Lorraine, it seems, wanted to know about extending the Confidence and Supply deal with Fianna FÃ¡il.â€œI told her the truth. I said itâ€™s not easy negotiating with the Fianna FÃ¡il front bench,â€ said Leo, winding up for the big punchline.We feared we might suffocate in tumbleweed but a person began to clap, very loudly, and everyone joined in. Or at least that part of the hall which wasnâ€™t wiped out by the lead balloon which was falling on them.The Taoiseach was clear Fine Gael would not go down the populist road of other parties by buying votes with all sorts of expensive promises like tax cuts and the like. Then he promised he would get middle income earners out of the top tax bracket and make sure more of them qualify for childcare subsidies.â€œAs they should . . . Theyâ€™re worth it! Youâ€™re worth it!â€People may scoff and say that money should be used for far more pressing causes, but we noticed one of the private security men in the black bomber jackets standing at his position, hands held low, enthusiastically applauding.It certainly went down well with the crowd.Going forward was thrust forward quite a lot in a speech which was not backward about coming forward. It will come as no surprise that â€œTaking Ireland Forward Togetherâ€ is Fine Gaelâ€™s new off-the-shelf slogan, from the clunky and unoriginal side of the marketing aisle.Did the Yanks see them coming and sell it to the party? Taking Ireland For . . . a ride? A fool? A small fortune? Hours of happy slogan and poster vandalising in prospect here.There was also a strangely jarring American word in Leoâ€™s speech when he told the nation â€œOnly Fine Gael can be trusted to protect your job, your pocketbook and your pension.â€Then again, everyone knows Fine Gael ladies keep their pocketbooks in their fanny packs beside their cellphones.All in all it was a Hobbitâ€™s front door of a speech â€“ very low key.He isnâ€™t a great speaker. If he was, Simon would have said it. But the delegates loved him, and he made up for his flat address by staying behind on stage for the best part of an hour posing for photographs with delegates.But the evening was rescued in style by the big screen in the Ballroom and a memorable rugby match. Leo was among cheering delegates urging on the home team to a memorable win over the All-Blacks. An elated crowd left Citywest in buoyant mood, all keyed up and ready for action.Heading home happy and sweatinâ€™, even if the man who was supposed to do it wasnâ€™t responsible. That doesnâ€™t matter, Leo was exalted by association. A lucky general, along with everything else.Earlier in the day, for the benefit of party members and not for general release, a spoof video of various Ministers trying to be funny was aired.It was an entertainingly awful â€œspin the wheelâ€ game where Cabinet members answered light-hearted questions. The whole farrago took place with whacky sit-com music running in the background.â€œAre you ready to play the game?â€ the Minister for Justice was asked.â€œIâ€™m ready to roll . . .,â€ answered Charlie Flanagan, perpetrating a mortifying thumbs up.Then Heather Humphreys spun the wheel unenthusiastically.â€œWhat item did Leo Varadkar famously put in the dishwasher in 2017?â€What did the TÃ¡naiste have to promise his five-year-old daughter to make sure she would greet Pope Francis?â€œA kitten. A live one. Itâ€™s known as The Holy Spirit in our house,â€ replied Coveney.One viewer said his toes were curling so much he could scratch his arse with his foot.As soon as Leo left the stage, his team sent an email to all his subscribers.â€œIâ€™ve just finished. Can you help?â€Where to start . . .

title: parliament accused conflict interest rejects nda debate
story: John Bercow, the Speaker of the House of Commons, refused to allow Maria Miller to ask an urgent question on the use of gagging clauses by the wealthy and powerfulHouse of CommonsMaria Miller, the Tory MP, last night accused Parliament of a conflict of interest over Britain's MeToo scandal after it emerged she had been blocked from questioning the Government over it.The Daily  can reveal John Bercow, the Speaker of the House of Commons, yesterday refused to allow Ms Miller, who chairs the women &amp equalities Commons select committee, to ask an urgent question on the use of gagging clauses by the wealthy and powerful, including the Topshop tycoon Sir Philip Green.Helen Jones, chairman of the petitions select committee, also rejected calls to allow a parliamentary debate on non-disclosure agreements (NDAs) after two separate petitions demanding a change to the law between them secured 250,000 signatures. It came as Topshop was forced to cancel a launch party for its latest collection after designer Michael Halpern pulled out.Ms Miller declined to comment on Mr Bercow's refusal but, writing for The Daily , highlighted the Commons' own use of NDAs, on which it spent Â£2.4million between 2013 and 2017. Perhaps Parliament would be better placed to challenge this abuse of the law if it weren't also caught up in the use of NDAs, she argued.There have been more than 50 severance agreements, most including confidentially clauses, relating to House of Commons staff alone over the past five years. Last week, Ms Miller called on Mr Bercow to resign over a report into bullying in the Commons, something he himself has been accused of. Andrew Bridgen, one of Mr Bercow's most vocal critics, said: He should recuse himself from any further participation in the House's response to the culture change required. In fact, the best thing he can do is stand down as Speaker.A spokesman for Mr Bercow, who has denied bullying or any knowledge of pay-offs to alleged victims, said it might be thought premature to grant an urgent question on NDAs given the Government's response to Ms Miller's committee's report on misconduct in the workplace was expected shortly.Ms Jones said her committee would love an NDAs debate but could not sanction it unless a petition was lodged on Parliament's website. The impact of the scandal on Sir Philip's retail empire began to emerge last night after Mr Halpern withdrew from a launch party for his line. He is understood to have felt unable to attend after Sir Philip was named as the businessman behind an injunction preventing The  publishing allegations against him of sexual harassment and racial discrimination. A fashion insider said: His brand is about female empowerment. That's his ethos. He couldn't go ahead with this, it wouldn't be a good look. It would be awkward. I can't imagine celebrities would want to be associated with Philip Green. He's in a tricky situation. title: 45 minutes ideal commute according scientists
story: Participants were happy to increase their commute times to find a better house, but not to more than 45 minutesTransport and industryPeople are happy to commute up to 45 minutes if it means living in a good area or reaching a desirable job, but not longer, according to a study.Researchers analysing the habits of 4,248 workers over seven years found that inidual whose commutes to their place of employment were longer than 45 minutes tended to move house in order to reduce their travel times.Conversely, those who started the study period with commutes shorter than 45 minutes were often prepared to increase their travel times in order to move to a better home or to reach a more desirable job located further away.The study also found that those who did not move house over the study period were more likely to have shorter commutes to begin with and to be home-owners with decent to high incomes.Meanwhile people who changed residences but remained at the same workplace, had middle-range incomes and upgraded from tenancy to ownership, which lengthened commutes.The study by the Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing is published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.It follows data suggesting that one in seven commuters is now spending two hours or more each day travelling to and from work.A study by the University of the West of England last year found that a 20-minute increase in commute time, averaged out across the year, is equivalent to a 19 per cent pay cut for job satisfaction.Transport and industryPlease review our commenting policyRemainersâ€™ threats of EU non-cooperation if there is no deal are an admission we should leaveTory Brexiteers admit their attempt to unseat Theresa May has stalled amid bitter in-fightingComment: Toppling Theresa May risks a bitter second referendum and a Corbyn governmentBBC Natural History Unit boss: why we stepped in to save the penguinsComment: Never mind Brexit, Theresa May is a terrible Prime Minister - title: oxford professor launches legal action disinherited mother met
story: Law and orderAn Oxford University professor has launched legal action claiming he was disinherited by his mother and lost out on her Â£1.25m home after she fell in love with a female lawyer half her age.Prof Christopher Gosden said his mother Jean Weddell, a distinguished physician, had resolved to leave him her London home and had set up a trust in order to ensure he received the Edwardian property or the proceeds of its sale.However, when she died in 2013, Prof Gosden, director of the Institute of Archaeology at Oxford, discovered that the home had been sold without his knowledge three years earlier and that just Â£5,000 remained in her estate.Ms Weddell had changed her will after falling in love with Wendy Cook, a barrister 37 years her junior.Â The pair entered a civil partnership in 2007, when she was 78, and she had gifted much of her estate to her new partner while leaving nothing to her son, according to papers lodged at the High Court.Â Prof Gosden has lodged a writ claiming that the trust scheme his mother had set up in 2003 to minimise inheritance tax ought to have protected the house, or the money from its sale, and delivered it to him and his wife, Jane Kaye, an Oxford professor in the field of health law and policy.Â Dr Jean Weddell, who died aged 84 in 2013.Â Both Prof Gosden and Prof Kaye were appointed trustees of the scheme, along with Ms Weddell.But in 2010 his mother made a new will and sold her house in Kennington, south London without her telling him.He and his wife are suing the solicitors responsible for drawing up the trust agreement, claiming they made a mistake by leaving a loophole which allowed his mother to sell her house without his knowledge.Prof Gosden argues that the lawyers should have advised him to take the protective step of registering a restriction on the sale of the house with the Land Registry, so that his mother could not dispose of it without him and his wife being informed.But the solicitors deny being at fault, and say the Professor should have sued his own mother if he was unhappy.Katherine McQuail, for the solicitors, says in their defence to the claim: The claimants' remedy for any step taken by Ms Weddell in breach of contract or in breach of trust was to sue her for such breach.Wendy Cook, the civil partner of Dr Jean WeddellShe argues that it was not the lawyers' role to advise Ms Weddell on the advantages or disadvantages of the trust and states that they had not acted for, or advised, Prof Gosden and his family in any capacityâ€.The solicitors also deny that the objective of the trust was to achieve a transfer of the property to Prof Gosden and his family.They acted neither negligently, nor in breach of contract, and could have taken no steps that would have prevented Ms Weddell dealing with her own property as she wished, says Ms McQuail.Ms Weddell, who died in 2013 aged 84, was one of the first female students at St Thomas's Hospital Medical School in 1947 and worked in both Korea and Jordan before carrying out groundbreaking work with stroke patients.When Prof Gosden was born, she gave him up for adoption and he was taken to live in Australia by his adoptive family but returned to the UK and reestablished a relationship with his mother in 1987, Â the writ states.The case came before the High Court last week for a pre-trial review. title: currency exchange rates what causes change euro dollar pound sterling
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsWhy do exchange rates fluctuate, often dramatically?Click to followThe IndependentThe poundâ€™s up, the poundâ€™s down. The dollarâ€™s soaring, the dollarâ€™s plummeting.But why? What moves currency markets? Why do exchange rates fluctuate, often dramatically?The answer is supply and demand. If demand for a currency goes up its price will rise. If demand falls, its price will tend to fall.But what can determine supply and demand?First, expectations of national economic weakness. Think of things like war, or a natural catastrophe, or some other radical change of circumstances with economic implications. A good example is the impact of the Brexit referendum on sterling. So whatâ€™s going on? Bad macroeconomic news implies lower economic activity and less inward investment from abroad due to lower returns. That makes investing money in a currency less attractive to external investors, so thereâ€™s less demand for a currency from abroad. The result? The exchange rate goes down.Second, expectations of national economic strength. This works the other way. It can be sparked by unexpectedly good GDP figures. Perhaps a new oil or gas discovery. Sometimes itâ€™s driven by political decisions. Think of US dollar currencyâ€™s response to Trumpâ€™s election victory, with him having promised tax cuts and an infrastructure spending splurge in the campaign. These were all expected to lift the growth rate, at least in the short term. Macroeconomic strength means interest rates likely to rise to head off domestic inflation. Rising domestic interest rates mean better returns which means more demand from abroad. The result? The exchange rate goes up.But itâ€™s important to remember that the value of a currency is a relative measure. A nationâ€™s currency is always valued in a foreign currency. So sterling is measured in dollars or euros or yen or rand or the Mongoloian togrog, you name it. If the value of another countryâ€™s currency rises that means yours can fall, even if nothing has really changed about the economic outlook for your country. When the dollar rises against the pound it can be because the US economy is doing well. It doesnâ€™t necessarily mean the outlook for the UK economy has got any worseAnd a final word of caution. Donâ€™t make the mistake of believing that currency moves are always based on rational and careful assessments by currency traders and investors of underlying economic conditions. In the short term â€“ and possibly even the long term â€“ there is a very large dose of knee-jerk sentiment, herding and, sometimes, blind panic involved.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other usersâ€™, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other usersâ€™, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no Independent Minds comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsEnter your email to follow new comments on this article.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Want to discuss real-world problems, be involved in the most engaging discussions and hear from the journalists? It is a compromise. But it is hard-won progress,' said Ms FairbairnThe money that firms are being forced to spend in preparation for a potential no-deal Brexit next March is a waste, the director-general of the CBI has complained.In a speech to the business lobby groupâ€™s 2018 conference on Monday Carloyn Fairbairn said â€œnot one penny of it will create new jobs or productsâ€.This is what day one of a no-deal Brexit could look likeâ€œBrexit is consuming government â€“ every politician, every civil servant. And it is also consuming British business,â€ she said.â€œOur firms are spending hundreds of millions of pounds preparing for the worst case â€“ and not one penny of it will create new jobs or new products.â€œInvestment is flooding out of the right areas like skills and tech, and into areas which do absolutely nothing to help our productivity. Some of it is leaving our country altogether. While other countries are forging a competitive future, Westminster seems to be living in its own narrow world, in which extreme positions are being allowed to dominate.â€Despite the almost universally hostile political reception for Theresa Mayâ€™s draft Withdrawal Agreement with the European Union, unveiled last week, the CBI&nbsphas called on MPs to back it since it avoids the risk of a cliff-edge for firms on 29 March 2019.â€œThe Prime Ministerâ€™s agreement is not perfect. It is a compromise. But it is hard-won progress,â€ said Ms Fairbairn.A no-deal Brexit next March would be expected to ground UK flights and result in severe disruption of haulage deliveries through UK ports.UK-based manufacturers and retailers which have â€œjust-in-timeâ€ supply chains have warned of major problems in such circumstances and said that they have limited facilities for stock-piling.Last week, Ms May told the House of Commons: â€œWe can choose to leave with no deal, we can risk no Brexit at all, or we can choose to united and support the best deal that can be negotiatedâ€.In her speech, Ms Fairbairn&nbspagain castigated Labourâ€™s nationalisation plans, saying that when it was last tried in the 1970s â€œit ushered in one of the darkest periods in our countryâ€™s modern economic historyâ€.But she also had a message for those hardline Brexiteers who have presented leaving the EU as an opportunity for wholesale deregulation.â€œExtreme market ideology does not get us much further. Becoming a hustling cowboy nation with minimal regulation is not what people want. Nor is it what business wants,â€ she said.On immigration, Ms Fairbairn&nbspalso rejected the recent advice from the independent Migration Advisory Committee that the Government should, post-Brexit, only allow in skilled workers who can command a salary of more than Â£30,000 and also the Governments pledge to reduce net migration to the tens of thousands.â€œWhat has been proposed so far wonâ€™t work,â€ she said.â€œThe idea that anyone earning less than Â£30,000 canâ€™t contribute to our economy, for instance. title: international space station iss location nasa orbit 20 birthday anniversary
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsLargest manned object in space built with participation of 16 nations at cost of Â£93.4bnClick to followThe Independent TechThe International Space Station (ISS) is celebrating its 20th birthday.Russian space agency Roscosmos kicked off the project to build a successor to the Mir and Skylab stations&nbspon 20 November 1998&nbspwhen it launched its Zarya module from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan.Two weeks later, Nasa followed suit with its own component, Unity.&nbspThe pair were joined&nbspin low-earth orbit and started a&nbsp13-year construction effort that would see a&nbspvast artificial satellite produced, serving&nbspas an observatory, laboratory and staging post from which mankind could advance its understanding of our own world and those beyond.The ISS was also a landmark act of co-operation between the United States and Russia, the old Cold War foes definitively laying to rest decades of nuclear tensions to share the expertise both sides had accumulated during and after the Space Race of the 1960s to further the common good.&nbspAstronauts who crash landed will get back into same rocketTo celebrate the 20th anniversary of this extraordinary project, intended to last another 10 years at least, here are 20 facts you might not know about the ISS:1. Sixteen nations were involved in its construction. In addition to the US and Russia, those were: Belgium, Brazil, Canada, Denmark, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the Netherlands, Norway, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and the UK. &nbsp2. No fewer than 136 space flights from seven different types of craft were deployed to deliver parts to the engineers. The large modules were delivered on 42 assembly flights: 37 on US shuttles, five on Russian Proton and Soyuz rockets.3. The result is the largest manned object in space, 357ft long â€” just a yard short of a full-length American football field.4. The ISS weighs 419,725kg including the weight of spacecrafts, of which it can accommodate as many as six at any one time.5. It is the single most expensive object ever built at Â£93.4bn.6. It is the third brightest object in the night sky after the moon and Venus.7. The ISS travels at a speed of 4.791 miles per second, fast enough to go to the moon and back in a single day.Nasa space shuttle Endeavour (Getty)8. At that pace it orbits the earth approximately once every 90 minutes or 16 times in a 24-hour period, meaning it passes through 16 sunsets and sunrises per day. It passes over 90 per cent of the earthâ€™s population in the course of its orbital path.9. The space station has more living space than a six-bedroom house, offering six sleeping quarters, a gym and a 360-degree bay window, but only two bathrooms. There are no chairs either â€”&nbspastronauts taking time out to eat their three square meals a day of canned and dehydrated food have to float&nbspgently in zero gravity. The atmosphere aboard is aboard is described as having a â€œmetallic-ionisation-type smellâ€.Aki Hoshide participates in extravehicular activity outside the International Space Station (NasaGetty)10. So far 230 people from 18 nations have visited the ISS&nbspand it has been continuously occupied since November 2000.11. Nasaâ€™s Peggy Whitson set the record for the longest time living and working in space at 665 days on 2 September 2017, before returning to earth the next day.12. Astronauts aboard have completed 205 spacewalks since 1998 to carry out construction jobs, maintenance and repairs.ISS crew members&nbspfrom the Vatican (Reuters)13. The physical toll all this takes on astronauts is considerable: crew members need to work out in the station's gym for at least two hours a day to mitigate the loss of bone and muscle mass and maintain the normal bodily health they would experience on terra firma.14. Four different delivery craft supply the crew with food&nbspand equipment: Orbital ATKâ€™s Cygnus, SpaceXâ€™s Dragon, JAXAâ€™s HTV and the Russian Progress.15. A Water Recovery System on board reduces the astronauts' dependence on these cargo craft by 65 per cent through recycling. Even urine is reused.Created with Sketch.A visitorâ€™s guide to the International Space Station Show all 8Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.The training's over, Timâ€¦ next stop: the greatest lab in the universe! (NASA)Your sleep pod â€“ don't forget your sleeping bag (NASA)Alcohol is barred on the ISS, but you won't escape daft initiations â€“ such as drinking a blob of floating water (NASA)Keep your fingers crossed for a pop at a spacewalk: repairs are scheduled for January (GettyNASA)Floating about is a joy, but it takes about a month to crack it (NASA)There's work to do, including 300 ongoing experiments and repairs to billion-dollar devices (NASA)Wash down the spicy prawns with some recycled urine (NASA)Savour every second soon enough, you'll be brought back down to Earth (NASA)The training's over, Timâ€¦ next stop: the greatest lab in the universe! (NASA)Your sleep pod â€“ don't forget your sleeping bag (NASA)Alcohol is barred on the ISS, but you won't escape daft initiations â€“ such as drinking a blob of floating water (NASA)Keep your fingers crossed for a pop at a spacewalk: repairs are scheduled for January (GettyNASA)Floating about is a joy, but it takes about a month to crack it (NASA)There's work to do, including 300 ongoing experiments and repairs to billion-dollar devices (NASA)Wash down the spicy prawns with some recycled urine (NASA)Savour every second soon enough, you'll be brought back down to Earth (NASA)16. Oxygen is generated by a process of electrolysis: current captured from the stationâ€™s acre of solar panels is used to split water molecules into hydrogen and oxygen.17. The ISS's internal pressurised volume is 32,333 cubic feet, which is roughly equivalent to that of a Boeing 747 passenger jet.18. Software on board the ISS monitors 350,000 sensors checking in on crew health and safety. The station meanwhile carries 50 computers and eight miles of wire, enough to run around the perimeter of Central Park in New York City.19. The ISS provided the set for the first music video ever shot outside of our atmosphere when commander Chris Hadfield&nbspmade a short film set to&nbspDavid Bowieâ€™s â€œSpace Oddityâ€ up there in May 2013.20. To mark its turning 20, the ISS is getting a Refabricator for a birthday present. story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsThe smartphone giant previously mocked Apple for its iPhone X designClick to followThe Independent TechSamsung may have figured out a way to make its&nbspforthcoming flagship smartphone, presumably called the Galaxy S10, a&nbspcompletely full-screen device that doesn't feature a notch design.A new patent submission shows a phone design that uses a small circle in the top left of the screen in order to incorporate a front-facing camera.The patent, first spotted by Dutch website LetsGoDigital (https:en.letsgodigital.orgsmartphonessamsung-galaxy-s10-smartphone)&nbsp, shows what the South Korean electronics giant may have in mind for its 2019 flagship phone.LetsGoDigital)When Apple launched the iPhone X in 2017, Samsung made fun of the front notch that was included at the top of the screen.In a widely publicised advert, Samsung showed a man standing in a line outside an Apple store with a notch-shaped haircut.Created with Sketch. Show all 12Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Apple's design also allows the iPhone maker to cram in facial recognition technology â€“ it is not clear if or how Samsung's new design will include this.It is not the first sign that Samsung's next smartphone will be a genuinely all-screen device, with several alleged prototypes shared on social media showing a full-screened phone.S10 (Creative Commons, mobil-helden)Other rumours surrounding the Samsung Galaxy S10&nbspinclude a self-healing screen, which could put an end to scratched displays.&nbspA Samsung patent from August describes an anti-fingerprinting composition having a self-healing property, and a film, and a device including the anti-fingerprinting composition,  for use in a portable electronic device such as a smart phone or tablet.The patent did not specifically mention the Galaxy S10&nbspby name, and a focus on the screen's functionality in a foldable device hints it could feature in Samsung's forthcoming folding phone.Samsung foldable phone: Price and release date revealed in leakThe Galaxy S10 is also expected to feature an improved camera, potentially with a vertical alignment of lenses.S10 could include a triple-lens camera (Creative Commons, mobil-helden)The triple-lens&nbspcamera arrangement would put it alongside the Huawei P20&nbspPro, improving upon the dual-lens design of its predecessors.The expected release date for the Galaxy S10 is early 2019, with Mobile World Congress in Barcelona in February touted as the potential host for the launch.Share your thoughts and The astronomers who found it named it Apep, after the Egyptian god of chaos, reflecting the intensity and vastness of the system but also the curling shape of the snake-god, which matches its whirling appearance.The two bright stars&nbsporbit each other every hundred years or so, according to the researchers. As they do, a fast wind is thrown off, moving as fast as&nbsp12 million kilometres an hour.Eventually the system is going to throw out a&nbsplong-duration gamma-ray burst, according to the astronomers who found it. They can last just a couple of seconds but throw out as much energy as the sun will emit in its whole lifetime.The two stars appear to be rotating so fast that they are close to ripping each other apart. IndependentThe mounds are waste points for soil and other matter excavated from a vast underground tunnel networkA termite super-colony which s an area the size of Great Britain&nbsphas been under construction since the time of the pyramids in ancient Egypt, scientists have found.Researchers studying the vast landscape of 200 million cone-shaped mounds in northeast Brazil sampled soil from 11 locations and found that some began construction around 3,820 years ago.At around 2.5 metres tall,&nbsp9 metres wide at the base, and spread across 230,000 square kilometres, it&nbsprepresents a vast earth-moving endeavour â€“&nbspbut the&nbspmounds are not inidual termite nests.Instead, each one is a â€œwaste pointâ€&nbspwhere termite workers dump soil and other matter excavated in the production of a vast subterranean tunnel network which they have used to traverse the landscape in search of food for millennia.â€œThis is apparently the worldâ€™s most extensive bioengineering effort by a single insect species,â€ said Roy Funch of Universidade Estadual de Feira de Santana in Brazil, one of the authors of the report.â€œPerhaps most exciting of all â€“ the mounds are extremely old â€“ up to 4,000 years, similar to the ages of the pyramids.â€Funch)The mounds are largely hidden from view by caatinga,&nbspan assortment of thorny, desert-like vegetation unique to Brazil, and were only revealed to international scientists a few decades ago as the land was cleared for pasture.Now sampling from the oldest mounds has revealed the&nbsparea is of comparable age to some of the oldest termite colony structures known to exist&nbspin Africa, while others began construction around 600 years ago.They have developed in response to the drought-sculpted environment where the annual leaf fall is a boom time for harvesting food, punctuated by long periods where resources are more scarce.â€œThese mounds were formed by a single termite species that excavated a massive network of tunnels to allow them to access dead leaves to eat safely and directly from the forest floor,â€ said Professor Stephen Martin, a social insect expert from&nbspthe University of Salford and&nbspanother of the authors.â€œThe amount of soil excavated is over 10 cubic kilometres, equivalent to 4,000 great pyramids of Giza, and represents one of the biggest structures built by a single insect species.â€œItâ€™s incredible that, in this day and age, you can find an â€˜unknownâ€™ biological wonder of this sheer size and age still existing, with the occupants still present.â€The mounds are not the only entry points to the tunnel network â€“ termites emerging at night to scavenge use dozens of smaller entrances between each waste point.Dying 700-year-old tree put on drip to save it from termitesTermites devour 10m rupees at bankAnts rescue injured workers during wars with termites, study findsBy inspecting mounts cut in half by&nbsproad building projects, Professor Martin and colleagues also showed they lack the complex honeycomb of tunnels&nbspusually associated with a termite nest.Instead each includes a single large central tunnel â€“ measuring 10 cm across â€“ connecting to the underground tunnel network and a series of horizontal â€œgalleriesâ€ containing dead leaves or larvae.â€œThe&nbsptunnels&nbspare&nbspnever&nbspleft&nbspopen&nbspto&nbspthe&nbspenvironment,&nbspruling&nbspout&nbsptheir&nbspuse&nbspas&nbspa&nbspventilation&nbspsystem,â€ which left them puzzled as to how and why they had been created at such regular intervals.One theory is that each mound was from a competing colony, but when they transferred termites to a&nbsprival neighbouring mound they were not swarmed and attacked.This&nbspsuggests&nbspthat they intermingle underground rather than competing, and&nbspwhen they did the same test with termites taken from mounds 50km away the attack response was immediate.It suggests there must be shared pheromone scent cues used across&nbsp the tunnel network which identify&nbsplocal neighbours.Professor Martin and his colleagues suggest that these scent markers may exist at each mound point to&nbspensure every termite uses it to remove soil and waste, leading to the equal spacing.Great Pyramid of GizaWonder of the Ancient WorldShare your welfare in UK&nbspâ€˜discreditedâ€™&nbsphis findingsClick to followIndy PoliticsAmber Rudd has launched an attack on a UN report about the state of poverty in Britain in her first Commons appearance as work and pensions secretary.In her new role as&nbsphead of&nbspthe department that oversees UK welfare policy, Ms Rudd said the language used by the UN special rapporteur on&nbspextreme poverty and human rights was â€œwholly inappropriateâ€ and â€œdiscredited a lot of what he was sayingâ€.Fridayâ€™s&nbspreport found that&nbsppolicies and drastic cuts to social support were entrenching high levels of poverty and inflicting unnecessary misery in one of the richest countries in the world, adding that Brexit was exacerbating the problem.Amber Rudd becomes sixth DWP secretary in less than three yearsAmber Rudd appointed as work and pensions secretaryAmber Rudd says parts of Home Office 'did not have a grip' on policyThe special rapporteur Philip Alston presented a withering assessment of Britainâ€™s approach to its poorest citizens, predicting a 7 per cent rise in child poverty, and detailing a 60 per cent increase in homelessness since 2010 and exponential growth in the number of food banks.In light of his findings, he condemned the British governmentâ€™s â€œpunitive, mean-spirited and often callousâ€ treatment of the countryâ€™s poorest and most vulnerable.In the House of Commons on Monday, Ms Rudd was asked by shadow work and pensions secretary Margaret Greenwood whether, in light of the UNâ€™s warnings that universal credit could put many people at risk of destitution, she would end&nbspthe governmentâ€™s â€œstate of denialâ€ and stop the rollout of the new benefit system.Responding, Ms Rudd said: â€œI have seen the report by the rapporteur and I must say I was disappointed to say the least by the extraordinary political nature of his language. We on this side of the House will always engage with professionals, with experts, with NGOs, we are not so proud we donâ€™t think we can learn as we try to adjust universal credit for the benefit of everybody.â€œBut that sort of language was wholly inappropriate and discredited a lot of what he was saying, but we look forward to working with experts in the area to make sure we get the right outcome for the people we want to look after.â€Amber Rudd becomes sixth DWP secretary in less than three yearsEarlier in the debate, Justin Tomlinson, minister for family support, housing and child maintenance, said the government â€œdisagreedâ€ with Mr Alstonâ€™s findings, and defended universal credit as a â€œsimplified benefit system that helps some of the most vulnerable people in societyâ€.The remarks from the new work and pensions secretary&nbspand Mr Tomlinson will exacerbate concerns raised in the UN report that ministers are â€œin a state of denialâ€&nbspover the state of poverty in&nbspBritain.&nbspDelivering his findings on Friday, Mr Alston&nbspsaid: â€œWhat I found in my discussions with ministers, is basically a state of denial. The ministers with whom I met have told me that things are going well, that they donâ€™t see any big problems, and they are happy with the way in which their policies are playing out.â€œBut itâ€™s of course not the story that I heard in my travels through Wales, Scotland, Northern Ireland and in quite a few cities in England.â€Theresa May appointed Ms Rudd as the new work and pensions secretary last week after Esther McVey stood down from the role on Thursday in protest at the prime ministerâ€™s Brexit deal.The decision prompted immediate criticism from opposition parties, who suggested Ms Ruddâ€™s conduct when the Windrush scandal emerged â€“ a fiasco that forced her to resign â€“ should disqualify her from a top government job.Critics also warned that she&nbspwas taking on a â€œpoisoned chaliceâ€ as she becomes the sixth work and pensions secretary in less than three years.The Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are given a voice on the final Brexit deal.Sign our petition hereShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other usersâ€™, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - far-western Xinjiang region said people â€œpoisoned by extremism, terrorism and separatismâ€ would be treated leniently if they surrendered within the next 30 days.The move comes as Beijing faces increasing international scrutiny over its treatment of the Uighur Muslim minority and other ethnic groups living in Xinjiang.China forcing ethnic Uighurs to serve as intelligence assetsChina urged to extremism.The government message to Muslims in Xinjiang warned actions from contact with overseas terror groups to conservative Islamic behaviour would require iniduals to turn themselves in.Those who reject government-provided housing, alcohol or cigarettes on the basis they are&nbspâ€œharamâ€, or forbidden by Islam, were ordered to notify authorities.Advocating people live their lives entirely in surrender themselves to the judicial organs within 30 days and to confess and hand over the facts of your crime,â€œ the notice said.China has for decades sought to stamp out Islam in order&nbspto attacks by Islamist extremists aiming to stir up tensions between the ethnic Han Chinese majority and the Muslim population.&nbspIn August, a United Nations human rights panel said it had received many credible reports that a million or more Uighurs and other minorities are being held in what resembles a â€œmassive internment camp that is shrouded in secrecyâ€.China insists it is not enforcing story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsCreated with Sketch.Analysis: Officials in Brussels hope representatives of&nbspthe remaining EU members&nbspwill&nbspnot seek to reopen negotiations, says&nbspJon StoneClick to followThe IndependentEU leaders will meet in Brussels on Sunday to sign off the Brexit deal struck with Theresa May, but you could be forgiven for asking what the point of the gathering is.After all, barring a last minute climbdown by Theresa Mayâ€™s detractors back home, the parliamentary arithmetic in Westminster looks fairly certain to defeat the plan.Still, the 27 countries will go through the motions this weekend, unless thereâ€™s some kind of intervention to oust the prime minister during the week. It would be a huge upset if they did not sign the agreement.The Daily Mail and the  could save us from a hard BrexitThere will not be any negotiation on the withdrawal agreement and its controversial backstop â€“ that, as far as the EU is concerned, is settled. Many countries have said as much publicly, in the face of cabinet Brexiteers demanding a rethink.But the second part of the deal, the future relationship, is far from sealed. If anything, EU states believe their negotiators might have given away too much to Britain: some are unhappy about concessions given with little in return, and want quid pro quos like guaranteed access to British waters for their fishing fleets.If there are changes there, things could get even trickier for the prime minister at home â€“ but these are real countries fighting for their own interests, not fantasy negotiating partners only committed to making things easy for the prime minister.None of the details for the summit are finalised yet, with an agenda set to be released later this week. Weâ€™re not sure at this point whether actual negotiation will take place at it, or whether it will just be a glorified rubber stamp. Brussels is known to favour the latter.I was on holiday during the Brexit chaos â€“ what did I miss?Legally, the summit has to take place, because only the European Council â€“ that is the 27 leaders meeting together in Brussels â€“ can sign off the deal and make the political declaration about the future relationship.Those in Brussels and other EU capitals do not like being seen to â€œmeddleâ€ in British politics, precisely because they know how poorly they are perceived.They mostly stayed out of the referendum, they accepted the result, and they have mostly declined to call for a rerun or anything to that effect.But it is possible some may break the habit of a lifetime at the gathering and urge British members of parliament to back the deal. If they do not do it directly, they might apply pressure through other means â€“ perhaps by warning of the prospect of no deal if it is voted down.This will be a difficult sell, however. Donald Tusk, the president of the European Council, said as recently as last week that Brexit could be stopped if Britain wanted. If the deal is voted down, staying in is still an option. And there is clearly not a majority for a no-deal departure in the House of Commons.But despite conspiracy theories from both some Brexiteers and the odd&nbspRemainer, everyone around the summit table will want a deal â€“ just not necessarily at any cost.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other usersâ€™, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our Community Guidelines.You may not agree with our views, or other usersâ€™, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or inciteful language is not acceptableDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Follow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no Independent Minds comments yet - be the first to add your thoughtsEnter your email to follow new comments on this article.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Want to discuss real-world problems, be involved in the most engaging discussions and hear from the journalists? story: Elephant trophies still prized 90 years on the from the age of Big White Hunters (Image: )Nearly 400 hunting trophies from endangered animals have been imported into the country in recent years, leading to fears they could be used as a cover for a &ldquobrutal and illegal trade.&nbspThe Government&rsquos wildlife champion Zac Goldsmith MP has gathered cross-party support for a Parliamentary Early Day Motion calling on ministers to stop the skins and body parts of animals hunted overseas from being brought home.&nbspRemarkably, endangered animals can legally be put in the crosshairs of hunters. A thriving international trophy enterprise exists, with big game hunters paying thousands of pounds through legitimate companies for the privilege of killing iconic creatures. Lion trophy hunts have prices of up to &pound20,000 and it costs up to &pound60,000 to claim an elephant trophy.                Squirrel who thinks he's Tommy Cooper wins photographer top awardThe hunting lobby maintains that offering big game safaris to shooters helps conserve wildlife, bringing vital funds into Africa and ensuring wild landscapes are preserved. It sees enthusiasts from the UK following in the footsteps of colonial Great White Hunters of the 1930s to claim trophies, according to figures that show the large number of specimens have &nbspbrought legitimately into the country in recent years.The Campaign to Ban Trophy Hunting says that over the last decade 2,500 trophies have been imported into the UK &ndash with almost 400 from species with the highest status under endangered species regulations.&ldquoTrophy hunting involves killing some of the most beautiful wild animal species on Earth simply for fun, says Mr Goldmsmith, Conservative MP for Richmond Park and North Kingston&ldquoIt is not only damaging to the endangered species themselves, the evidence shows that importing the parts also provides cover for a brutal illegal trade. &nbsp&ldquoIn more ways than one, it therefore harms the communities that rely of wildlife for tourism income. It is high time we banned the import of so-called trophies to the UK.MP Zac Goldsmith and Environment Secretary Michael Gove supporting rhino conservation (Image: PA)A prize tusker. One of hunting's Big Five (Image: )The Early Day Motion spells out concerns that hundreds of trophies from species threatened with extinction such as elephants, lions, hippopotamuses, leopards and rhinoceroses have been imported into the UK in recent years and states:Trophy hunting is having a negative effect on wildlife through the loss of significant numbers of healthy iniduals that are key to the survival of rapidly declining populationsUnsustainable rates of trophy hunting have caused some populations of Africa's big cats to declineHunting and poaching of elephants is outpacing their rate of reproductionTrophy hunting is cruel, immoral, archaic and unjustifiable, and can act as a cover for illegal poaching.Calling on the Government to halt trophy imports as a matter of urgency, the motion says nature tourism is a humane and more effective way of conserving wildlife and supporting communities.Hunting is causing some of Africa's big cat populations to decline (Image: )Eduardo Goncalves from the Campaign to Ban Trophy Hunting fears wildlife protection laws are also being exploited by poachers posing as trophy hunters.&ldquoMany people think the trade in endangered wildlife is banned but, in fact, trophy hunting is exempted, he explained. &ldquoIt&rsquos an extraordinary loophole which poachers are taking advantage of. Around 300 rhino horns are known to have been exported by phoney trophy hunters between 2009-2014 alone.Britain&rsquos status as global leader for wildlife and animal welfare is also under threat because of the lack of an import ban.He added: &ldquoThe Government promised to ban lion trophy imports in 2015 in the wake of the Cecil scandal unless it saw significant improvements in the industry.&ldquoThere have been very few if any changes but action has yet to have been taken here. Meanwhile, other countries such as Australia, France and the Netherlands have gone ahead and introduced their own import bans.The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs says trophies can only be brought into the country under strict rules.&nbsp&ldquoThe UK Government will not issue an import permit for a trophy unless the importer can show there has been no detrimental impact on endangered species and the trophy has been obtained from a sustainable hunting operation, said a Defra spokesman.
