title: Brexit news Michel Barnier UK EU withdrawal agreement deal Theresa May latest
story: The European Union's chief&nbspnegotatior&nbsprebuked claims that he has provoked London by allowing the political declaration to push for a single customs territory to become the basis for the future relationship. Mr Barnier told reporters in Brussels that the Prime Minister, through her contraversial Chequers plan, was the one to set out the request for a deal based on a customs union. He said: If you compare the guidance issued by European Council and the white paper from chequers, there&rsquos a free trade area... the minimum point of departure if you like.                BREXIT LIVE: &lsquoAction must be taken TODAY!&rsquo Tory rebels demand May R...                EU CRACKDOWN: Brussels warns NO NEW negotiations on May's Brexit dealMr Barnier said the EU had made a compromise moving towards a single customs area at the request of Mrs May as a solution for the vexed issue of the Irish backstop, the insurance policy to prevent a hard border on Ireland.This policy is expected to be used as a baseline for the future trading partnership, which will be negotiated during the 21-month transition period starting on March 29 2019.He said: The arrangement or agreement reached with Theresa May&rsquos Government on a single customs area is something on which we have moved in the UK&rsquos direction for first proposal of a backstop, I have taken in requests for a UK-wide backstop from the UK side.Mr Barnier also urged rebel Brexiteer MPs within Mrs May's Government to accept the terms agreed in the withdrawal agreement.&nbspBrexit news: Michel Barnier says Theresa May requested controversial future trade plans (Image: EbS)He said: &ldquoThe EU and the U.K. will have full control over their legislation and rule-making.&ldquoThis is essential on our side for the integrity of the single market it's essential for the U.K. in terms of taking back control.Warning off demands for potential changes to the deal, he added: &ldquoNow more than ever we must all remain calm &ndash and I will remain calm &ndash and keep our focus on the need for the U.K. to leave the EU in an orderly fashion.Mr Barnier was speaking after briefing EU27 ministers on the withdrawal agreement and the political declaration on the future relationship.                Brexiteer points out May's CRUCIAL mistake in EU negotiations He largely refused to comment on the key outstanding issue in the withdrawal agreement &ndash the end date for a possible extension to the transition period.But he said the EU27 had given him permission to ensure the 20XX date is filled in ahead of the special Brexit summit on Sunday.Mr Barnier said: I believe that all the governments have agreed to principle of possible extension but no decision has been made yet on this issue.I think it&rsquos rather sensible to keep the possibility of a one-off extension for a short period of time but no decision has been made yet I haven&rsquot seen any.Yesterday, EU diplomats revealed he had pitched the possibility of December 30 2022 to be the end date of the proposed extension but this must still be agreed with the UK.One EU diplomat said the decision will likely be taken for Thursday, when aides for the EU's heads of state meet to finalise plans for the Sunday summit.Mrs May is expected to visit Brussels ahead of the gathering with EU leaders to finalise the political declaration and withdrawal agreement.She will lead during a critical week of negotiations to ensure &ldquowe do get that final good deal for this country.&ldquoIt&rsquos the future relationship that actually delivers, if you like, on people&rsquos concerns in the withdrawal agreement, she added.Michel Barnier declares Brexit deal allows UK to 'take back control' in dig at Brexiteers (Image: EbS)Former Brexit secretary Dominic Raab, in an interview with the Sunday Times, urged Mrs May to stand up to Brussels bullies after resigning his position in opposition to elements of the Prime Minister's orce package.The Prime Minister has allowed Britain to be &ldquoblackmailed and bullied by Brussels, he warned.There were certainly swirling dark forces in the Commission, which you would hear rumbling that Northern Ireland was the price the United Kingdom must pay for leaving the EU, he added on his time spent in Brussels.&ldquoThat&rsquos totally irresponsible and reckless and not something we should give in to. The EU has become incredibly controlling and I think that&rsquos a sign of their insecurity as an organisation.Britain will be afforded little time to revisit the negotiating table on the withdrawal agreement, which Mrs May has been urged to do by Brexiteers MPs.Belgium&rsquos foreign minister Didier Reynders said: &ldquoIt's the best after so many months of negotiation and I'm sure that now we need to go further.&ldquoHere it will survive. We are waiting to the same situation in London but here in Brussels it will survive.Austrian Europe minister Gernot Blumen said: &ldquoI expect that the orce contract as it is on the table now will also be passed.&ldquoWe've had long months of difficult and intense negotiations and therefore I expect that what is on the table now will also be agreed upon.On Mrs May&rsquos political instability, he added: &ldquoOf course, I hope that everyone supports what has been negotiated.&ldquoWe have given Michel Barnier clear negotiation guidelines and the agreement we now have was created with this in mind.&ldquoI believe it is the best possible compromise, both sides have made compromises and therefore I hope that it will be agreed on by both sides.Germany's Europe minister Michael Roth said:No deal better than the one on the table can be reached.Luxembourg's Foreign Minister Jean Asselborn said:Any deal is better than no deal.I think that it's in the interests of the United Kingdom and the European Union, that this deal becomes reality.He added: I think the challenge now is for these&nbsp&nbspdogmatists to show whether that is true.I think Theresa May deserves praise for her position. 'No deal is better than a bad deal' has disappeared. 'Any deal is better than no deal' is now the slogan. That is right.This deal that is now on the table is the best there is. There is no better deal for this&nbsp&nbsp.&nbsp

Mr Corbyn claimed the&nbspEuropean Union&nbspwould be willing to re-open talks to establish a permanent customs union instead of forcing Britain into the single market and customs union to avoid a hard border in Northern Ireland. Theresa May's tentative Brexit deal has been criticised for threatening to keep the UK aligned to the bloc without an apparent way out.&nbspMr Corbyn said: We do think it would be much better if the Labour alternative of access to a market, a guaranteed, permanent form of customs union with the European Union and protection of rights in this country would be a better deal for this country as a whole.The EU is very used to 11th-hour stuff. story: Brexiteers fear the draft orce deal, which still needs to be approved by Parliament, is not what Leave voters want, as it will lock the UK into EU trade rules for years to come. In other words, the EU has the ultimate veto.Despite praising Brexit negotiators&rsquo &ldquosterling work on the accord and its &ldquoclever wording, Mr Blair warned of a &ldquofundamental ergence with Britain on the customs union: &ldquoIt&rsquos not reasonable. story: Divers came across a mysterious and bizarre 26-foot-long sea creature &nbspthat shifted its shape as it moved through the water. title: the alcoholic elephant dumbo film
story: An instant hit when he arrived at London Zoo in , Jumbo the African elephant could count Queen Victoria and her children among his many fans.But the adoring public had no idea that their gentle giant was forced to eat coins thrown at him, doped with alcohol and, as a baby, saw his mother hacked to death before his eyes.Jumbos tragic true story is so much more heartbreaking than the new trailer for the live action Dumbo film, directed by Tim Burton and set for release in March , suggests.Seeing the cute CGI baby elephant, you would never guess that in real le Jumbo was so aggressive that he had to be sold to PT Barnumâ€™s travelling circus in the US.Like Disneyâ€™s Dumbo, whose real name in the film is Jumbo, he quickly became the star attraction â€” until he was hit by a train and his le was cut short.Jumbo was captured by hunters in Eritrea and separated from his mother, who was slaughtered for her tusks and her hide as her cub looked on.Alone, confused and confined to a cage in Regent Streets newly established zoological gardens, orphaned Jumbo would grind his tusks down against the bars of his prison.In PT Barnums circus, poor Jumbo would be sedated with vast amounts of alcohol, knocking back bottles of champagne, port and whisky. His favourite food was biscuits soaked in spirits.On Jumbos journey from London to the US, he needed a daily allotment of whisky to keep him calm.He also used to eat anything thrown at him by visitors, including childrens toys and coins - hundreds of which were found in his stomach after he died.Last year,Â Sir David AttenboroughÂ investigated the le of the elephant claimed to be the largest to have ever lived in a BBC documentary.Sir David said: â€œIâ€™m going to look beyond Jumboâ€™s celebrity for the real elephant behind the myths.â€œHow big was he in reality  And what is the truth behind the mysteries that surround his tragic death â€Sir David and his team were given unique access to Jumboâ€™s remains at the American Museum of Natural History in New York, shedding light on the unforgettable true story behind an amazing elephant.When the team analysed Jumboâ€™s bones, it discovered evidence of how his le in captivity damaged him physically.After finding an unusual layering of old and new bone in his hip, Dr Richard Thomas, from the University of Leicester, said: â€œHe has many signs of stress and strain-related injuries.â€œThey must have been incredibly painful for him but may have reflected the use to which he was put.â€Often pictured giving rides to visitors at the zoo, it seems Jumbo may have been harmed by the ones who loved him most.And Jumbo had more than just a damaged hip.Dr Thomas added: â€œWhen we look at the knee we see all sorts of kind of changes in the bone that we wouldnâ€™t really expect to see in an elephant his age. Remember Jumboâ€™s only  and still growing.â€So Jumbo could have suffered from painful joint problems more associated with old age.Sir David concluded: â€œHis bones are more like an elephant in its s or s.â€PT Barnum claimed Jumbo was the largest African elephant on the planet, standing at around ft.But by analysing his leg bone, the team discovered he was around ft in at the time of his death.A typical wild African elephant of the same age measures around ft in.However, a crack in Jumboâ€™s leg bone reveals that he was still growing when he died.Dr Thomas said: â€œMale African elephants continue to grow until they are  so Jumbo had another  years of getting bigger.â€He may not have been as tall as Barnum claimed, but according to Sir David: â€œHe could have matched that claim had he lived.â€Jumboâ€™s calm nature during the day was in contrast to his behaviour at night.Sir David said: â€œHe would become possessed by terryingly violent rages in which he would smash the timbers of his enclosure.â€Jumbo was also prone to hurting himself in his confusion, even breaking off both tusks on one occasion. When they grew back, he ground them down against the stonework of his enclosure.His keeper, Matthew Scott, is said to have given him whisky to try to calm him down.The zooâ€™s superintendent, Abraham Bartlett, was convinced Jumbo was suffering from musth, a natural condition affecting young male elephants when they become sexually mature. It can cause them to become extremely aggressive.But Dr Vicki Fishlock, a researcher in Kenya, disagrees.She argues that musth would have caused Jumbo to be violent towards his keepers, too.And as Sir David pointed out: â€œThere is nothing in the historical records that Jumbo was ever violent towards people.â€A new clue emerged when the team found evidence of malformed teeth when studying Jumboâ€™s skull.Dr Thomas said: â€œWe can think of elephant teeth a bit like conveyor belts. They have six teeth but only one will be in wear on each side at any one time.â€œAnother one will be coming in underneath to replace it at the time which that tooth falls out.â€If a tooth does not wear down enough, it will not fall out and will block the new tooth, bending it out of shape. This would lead to terrible toothache.â€And Professor John Hutchinson, from the Royal Veterinary College, believes his toothache could have been made worse by the sticky buns pushed through his bars by visitors to the zoo.â€Sir David said: â€œAnyone whoâ€™s had toothache knows that it seems worse at night when you have no distractions, so maybe this is one of the explanations for Jumboâ€™s terrying nocturnal rages.â€Dr Holly Miller, from the University of Nottingham, took samples from Jumboâ€™s femur and rib bones to discover more about the food he was eating.She said: â€œWeâ€™re definitely seeing some suggestion that heâ€™s not getting the iety of diet that other elephants should.â€In the wild, African elephants have a ied diet of grass, leaves, twigs and even bark. Dr Miller says the pathologies ofÂ Jumboâ€™s teeth show they were soft and coming through at the wrong angle because they were not being used in the right way.â€œTheyâ€™re not being used to grind down the right food.According to a report at the time, his stomach was filled with English pennies, whistles, keys and rivets.It has been reported that Jumbo used to habitually eat coins which had been thrown into his enclosure - and the evidence supports this.Jumboâ€™s stuffed body was then kept at Tufts University in Massachusetts but was lost in a fire.Jumboâ€™s tail still remains, from which Dr Miller analysed hair to give a snapshot of his diet almost right before he died.It revealed a high amount of nitrogen, which suggests his body was under stress and was extracting as much nitrogen as possible from his diet to help repair it.In September , Barnumâ€™s circus went to Canada to perform in St Thomas, Ontario. Written records show that Jumbo was suffering from a sort of wasting disease at this time.After the show, Jumbo and a small elephant called Tom Thumb were being loaded on to the circus train when a freight train came hurtling towards them.Accounts of what happened next dfer, with Barnum claiming Jumbo sacriced his own le by running towards the train to save his friend Tom Thumb.But Sir David found more clues on a visit to the Elgin County Museum in the town where Jumbo died.Curator Mike Baker showed him a photo taken shortly after the collision, saying:Â â€œYou can see abrasions on his hide which match very nicely with the one good graphic from soon after the collision.â€It shows the train coming up behind Jumbo, which would have caused the scrapes on his body.Examining the drawing, Sir David said: â€œThat is the circus train with the box car that Jumbo was going to get into, and the locomotive would outrun him and hit him in the rear and thatâ€™s the end of poor Jumbo â€” not what Barnum said.â€And with no evidence of fractures on the skeleton, he concludes the most likely cause of death was internal bleeding - leading to a tragic end to a sad and short le.Even after his death, Jumbo was not allowed to rest.He was displayed in a gala in New York and paraded for four years as a roadside attraction.Dumbo will be released in theatres in March .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Itâ€™s quite a challenge, but letâ€™s have a go.Suppose, for the sake of argument, that Britain ended up with all the costs and obligations of European Union membership, but with no voice, no vote and no veto.Suppose we had to accept all the EUâ€™s rules â€” on technical standards, on environmental protection, on labour law â€” but no longer had any say over what those rules should be. title: time for decades of eu lies to end
story: Britain is a eurosceptic nation. title: russian girl bikinia frozen lake dive
story: The brave swimmer was filmed e-bombing into the lake in winter in her underwear and landing on the rock-hard ice - leaving her with a broken ankle and a bruised ego.In the video, the woman can be seen stripping down to just a black bra and thong before running to the edge of the lakes decking.She whips off her black bobble hat at the last minute and leaps off the edge in a bomb position with her knees tucked into her chest.But she lands with a horrying thud onto the lakes totally solid surface, leaving a crack in the ice.The woman sits on the water shrugging with her arms in the air, clearly confused and shocked at whats just happened.The man filming can be heard laughing as she regains enough strength to stand up on the ice and limp to the edge of the decking.Then she asks for a helping hand from the man behind the camera.She limps back to her seat, wincing with pain as she goes.The video ends with a photo of her left ankle heavily bandaged up - the injury she suffers from the painful error of judgement.The video was reportedly filmed in Balashikha, to the east of Moscow in Russia.Russians often jump into ice cold lakes as a celebration for the new year or Epiphany, a celebration of the baptism of Jesus.This practice usually takes place in January, the middle of Russian winter, although they probably check the water isnt frozen over first.

title: boy excluded school braids
story: Miles Coaleys mum spent four hours braiding his tresses on Thursday night.But when the -year-old rocked up with the new look at Ysgol Berwyn, in Bala, it didnt go went down like a lead balloon with teachers.Headteacher Andrew Roberts told Miles dad that until he changes his funky new do he would be barred from attending the school.Miless dad Brian told the Daily Post: I dont see what the problem is, Miles is only young, and he just wanted to look a little dferent.His mum spent four hours putting them in on Thursday night, he went into school on Friday in his home clothes because of Children in Need, and none of the teachers said anything and his friends really liked his look.But  minutes after dropping him off today, I got a call saying I had to pick him up because he wasnt welcome at the school until he had them taken them out.Part-time HGV driver Brian asked to speak to the head teacher Andrew Roberts.Mr Roberts explained that it was down to a school appearance policy, and wouldnt discuss it with me any further.Miles has taken them out as hes a good kid, he gets good grades andhe wasnt doing his mock GCSEs I would have kept him at home and made more of a stink about it.In a letter Ysgol Berwyn states: We expect pupils to style their hair in a tidy fashion, and not in a way that attracts attention.Examples of this are colouring their hair in unnatural colours, or in unusual styles.This policy was confirmed and adopted and implemented in the last school governors meeting and has been minuted.â€œIt would be beneficial for allMiles is able to remove the braiding and attend school and conform to the policy.

story: The mum-to-be sported a figure-hugging black dress with a white leaf pattern as she clasped Prince Harrys hand on the red carpet.It marks Meghans first appearance at the Royal Variety show - with tradition dictating that a senior member of the Royal Family attends each year.The star-studded bash at the London Palladium raises money to support hundreds of entertainers throughout the UK.Queen Elizabeth failed to appear for the sixth year running, despite turning up  times before her final outing in .The event will be hosted by Inbetweeners star Greg Davies.He said: I am delighted to host the Royal Variety.It is a role that I am wildly unsuited to and I will no doubt offend a great many people, but my Mum has a voracious appetite for meeting members of the Royal family and this seems a reasonable price to pay for the gt of le.Also performing will be Take That, Clean Bandit, Andrea Bocelli, and the cast of the Tina Turner musical.

title: theresa may resignations irish backstop
story: The â€˜Pizza Clubâ€™ gang of five Leave-backing senior ministers is insisting the PM toughen up the draft withdrawal agreement ahead of a landmark EU summit in seven days time to seal it. They want Britain to have a unilateral way out of the Irish backstop plan that could keep the UK in the customs union for many years otherwise.Allies of Development Secretary Penny Mordaunt and Commons Leader Andrea Leadsom say they could both quit by the end of the week unless Mrs May relents. But dfering tactics emerged among the rebel Cabinet group last night.Michael Gove has told friends he wonâ€™t now resign eventhe PM refuses ALL the Pizza Clubâ€™s demands. The Environment Secretary also thinks they have a greater chance of talking Mrs May out of agreeing a â€œsingle customs territoryâ€ with the EU as part of a joint vision for a future trade deal.Brexiteers fear the new phrase - in the far shorter Political Declaration that will accompany the orce deal - will spell an end to any hope of controlling our own trade deals where, and could be even worse than her Chequers plan for a soft Brexit.International Trade Secretary Liam Fox and Transport supremo Chris Grayling are also expected to sit tight now. The Pizza Club will try to meet today to draw up a plan of action, but by late last night no time had been set for the get together because of clashing diaries.One former Brexiteer minister, who has already resigned, told The Sun: â€œThe only way to make your case heard by the PM is to put your job on the line. Dominic Raab and Esther McVey did that, but the others havenâ€™t had the balls to yet and probably now wonâ€™t, so whatever they ask for is futile.â€To the dismay of Brexiteers yesterday, Mrs May argued that the backstop plan to ensure the Irish border stays open wouldnâ€™t workeither side could pull out of it.The PM told Sky News: â€œJust think aboutyou took out an insurance policy, andyou were coming up to the point where that insurance policy was being used, and suddenly people pull the plug on it for you  What would you think â€She added: â€œWe agreed the withdrawal agreement in principle last week. The focus this week will be on the future relationshipâ€.The PM also revealed she will fly to Brussels mid-week ahead of the summit to press the case personally for her vision of a future trade deal, pledging â€œan intense weekâ€ ahead. The draft Political Declaration that sets a course for the future relationship published last week was just seven pages long, as opposed to the orce dealâ€™s  pages.But Mrs May also revealed she hopes she will be able to persuade round Brexiteer doubters by painting in a more complete vision. The PM argued: â€œItâ€™s the future relationship that actually delivers on peopleâ€™s concerns in the withdrawal agreementâ€.She also warned coup plotters who want to replace her as Tory leader to think again, saying: â€œIt is not going to make the negotiations any easier, and it wonâ€™t change the Parliamentary arithmeticâ€.While admitting it has been â€œa tough weekâ€, askedshe had considered stepping down, Mrs May said: â€œNo, I havenâ€™tâ€.The PM will mount a fresh bid today to sell her deal by saying it will halt EU migrants from being able to â€œjump the queueâ€ to get into Britain. She will tell the CBIâ€™s annual conference this morning: â€œGetting back full control of our borders is an issue of great importance to the British peopleâ€.Writing for The Sun online today, former Cabinet minister Priti Patel says of the current future trade deal blueprint: â€œThe EU is tightening its grip on us and we get nothing â€“ certainly no trade deal - in . This agreement effectively means that the EU has taken back control.â€The DUP also called on the PM to renegotiate the backstop last night, arguing it splits Northern Ireland from the EU. Its Westminster leader Nigel Dodds said: â€œIt is clear that it is time to work for a better deal which does not undermine the integrity of the United Kingdomâ€Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn will again rule out voting for Mrs Mayâ€™s deal next month unless she deepens customs ties with the EU. In his own speech to the CBI, the Opposition boss say he would negotiate â€œa new comprehensive and permanent customs unionâ€The Toriesâ€™ sticking plaster plan for a temporary customs arrangement, with no clarity on how long it will last and no British say, can only prolong the uncertainty and put jobs and prosperity at risk.Two opinion polls yesterday revealed Labour has opened up a three point lead over the Tories after days of party turmoil over Brexit. As the Conservatives descended again into a full blown civil war, an Opinium poll for the Observer found the Tories have dropped five points to % while Labour has gained three to stand on %.And a ComRes poll for the Sunday Express and Sunday Mirror showed Labour on % versus versus the Conservatives on %.Alongside her woeful and deeply unpopular -page withdrawal agreement was a much sketchier seven-page political declaration that outlined ambitions for our future trading relationship with the EU. It said very little.Before negotiations formally start, it is vital Mrs May gets a lot more from the EU. Without doing so, she almost certainly wonâ€™t get the numbers to pass her Commons vote.Despite Mrs Mayâ€™s stark failings, the Tories must also avoid imploding.A leadership battle will be bloody and even Tory Brexiteers are split. Dominic Raab, who resigned last week as Brexit minister, yesterday admitted he would back Mrs Maythere was a vote of no confidence... What does thatsay about the viability of a coup And voters, already irritated by Tory squabbling, will punish themthey are dragged to the polls yet again.The terrying prospect of Jeremy Corbyn in No, with all the damage Britainâ€™s first Marxist PM could unleash, should be enough to stop the Tories from tearing themselves apart.To unite her party, the PM must start showing some energy, zeal and optimism about Britain.Our future, and hers, depends on it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit britain four more years theresa may admits transition extended to 2022
story: The Prime Minister told businesses she couldnt guarantee that she wouldnt need to extend the transition period beyond the end of .She would only promise we would be out of the EUs rules by the next general election - not scheduled to take place until .Addressing business leaders today at the CBIs annual conference, Mrs May defiantly told her critics she was the one to deliver Brexit.But she could not guarantee them that they would be in a new relationship with the EU by  as planned.She told them: I am clear that we have got an implementation period through to the end of .But she went on: Within the Withdrawal Agreement there is an extension to that further, as an alternative to putting in place the backstop for Northern Ireland.Mrs May added that she doesnt want that to have to come into place but it was therea deal was not secured by then.I think it is important that in delivering for the British people we are out of out of the implementation period before the next general election, she stressed.It comes after EU boss Michel Barnier proposed a maximum of a two year extension to the window - which would keep Britain in the Single Market and Customs Union.That would be more than SIX years after Britain voted to leave in June .The final date, currently marked in the Withdrawal Agreement as â€œXXâ€, needs to be thrashed out by the UK and EU ahead of a summit to sign off the deal next Sunday.During that time weâ€™ll have to accept free movement and pay substantial budget contributions estimated at Â£ billion a year.Most EU capitals agreed on New Yearâ€™s Eve  as a final end date for the transition at a meeting with Mr Barnier in Brussels yesterday.This morning Business Secretary Greg Clark said it could make sense to extend it for weeks or monthsneeded.He told Radio : It would be at our request and that would be a maximum period.If we were six weeks away from concluding a future economic partnership and agreeing that then it may make sense to extend the transition period.The Prime Ministers spokesperson said this morning: The Prime Minister has always been clear that the implementation period ends in advance of the next general election and that remains the case.

story: NewsDWP chief Amber Rudd launches vicious attack on UN report - minutes into her jobAmber Rudd prompted angry shouts as she branded the scathing benefit cuts report "wholly inappropriate" -  minutes into her first public appearanceShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video new-dwp-chief-amber-rudd-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tories new benefits chief has launched a vicious attack on a United Nations report - just minutes into her public debut in the job. Amber Rudd tore into a devastating UN report that accused ministers of being in denial about their mean-spirited and callous welfare reforms - notably six-in-one benefit Universal Credit. UN special rapporteur on extreme poverty and human rights Philip Alston called welfare cuts a political choice. And he declared: Government policies have inflicted great misery unnecessarily, especially on the working poor, on single mothers struggling against mighty odds, on people with disabilities who are already marginalised, and on millions of children. But Ms Rudd - who praised Esther McVey after replacing her on Friday - prompted shouts of anger as she branded Mr Alstons comments wholly inappropriate and extraordinarily political. Speaking today just  minutes into her first Commons QA of her job, the Work and Pensions Secretary said: Ive read it over the weekend.  I must say I was disappointed to say the least by the extraordinary political nature of his language. We on this side of the House will always engage with professionals, with experts, with NGOs. We are not so proud we dont think we can learn as we try to adjust Universal Credit for the benefit of everybody. But that sort of language was wholly inappropriate and actually discredited a lot of what he was saying.  Ms Rudd was forced to quit as Home Secretary after inadvertently misleading a Commons committee. But she was brought back into the Cabinet after showing keen loyalty to Theresa May. Her comments today came after Labours Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary attacked Tory ministers for being entirely dismissive of the UN report. Margaret Greenwood warned the government has been determined to press ahead with rolling out Universal Credit despite warnings disabled people could end up in destitution.  She called on Ms Rudd to end the governments state of denial and stop the rollout. The UN rapporteurs report said the roll out of the Universal Credit treated â€œclaimants like guinea pigsâ€ and threatened to â€œwreak havoc in real peoplesâ€™ lives.â€ The Mirror are demanding a halt to the expansion of Universal Credit and for a review to take place. We say there are three options:Redesign UC to be fit for purpose Axe it in favour of the old systemUC is unfixable Introduce a brand new systemSign our petition to stop the rollout of Universal Credit across Britain and to replace it with a fairer system by signing our petition. Mr Alston said during his visit he has spoken to people who â€œdepend on food banks and charities for their next meal, who are sleeping on friendsâ€™ couches because they are homeless and donâ€™t have a safe place for their children to sleep, who have sold sex for money or shelter, children who are growing up in poverty unsure of their future.â€ â€œThe Government has remained in a state of denial, and ministers insisted to me that all is well and running according to plan, he added. Ms Rudd looked solemn later in todays QA as she vowed to ensure Universal Credit is compassionate. She told the House of Commons: I know there are problems with Universal Credit despite its good intentions - I have seen them for myself. A Downing Street spokesman said we strongly disagree with the UN report. But Labours Ms Greenwood accused the government of being in total denial. â€œInstead of launching an attack on the UN, the Government must properly respond to the detailed evidence presented by the Special Rapporteur, she said.

story: NewsopinionKevin Maguire: Theresa May has to halt the Brexit wheel trapMirror columnist Kevin Maguire says that while time is running out, anything is possible before March  â€“ an extension, a referendum, a general electionShareCommentsByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  NOV NewsopinionTheresa May is trapped like a rat in a wheel "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailUnless or until Theresa May calls out the Brexit eliteâ€™s liars sheâ€™ll remain trapped like a rat in a wheel. Running hard to avoid falling over is a bad choice for a Prime Minister whoâ€™ll know privately her unpopular, chaotic plan is a far worse deal for Britain than remaining in Europe. Surrendering sovereignty to minimise economic damage is Mayâ€™s cowardly compromise. A braver PM would denounce forcefully the cost-free easy Britannia bonanza fabricated by fibbers Boris Johnson and Nigel Farage, then champion another referendum. The uncomfortable home truths about stockpiling medicines and food as well as troops on the streets put into perspective the Leaversâ€™ mythical poundmillion a week saving promise on the side of a bus. title: slammed boasting eu workers stop
story: NewsMay slammed for boasting EU workers will stop jumping the queue after BrexitScottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon blasted the Prime Ministers "offensive" and "disgraceful" remarks - as business chiefs raised serious concernsShareCommentsByDavid HughesDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  NOV NewsThe Prime Minister told the CBIs conference the post-Brexit system will be based on skills "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May was today slammed for boasting EU workers will stop jumping the queue after Brexit.The Prime Minister told the CBIs conference the post-Brexit system will be based on skills rather than where migrants come from.It will no longer be the case that EU nationals, regardless of the skills or experience they have to offer, can jump thequeue ahead of engineers from Sydney or software developers from Delhi, she said. But Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said the Prime Ministers language was offensive and disgraceful. The SNP leader said: That the case for Brexit has been reduced to such a miserable and self defeating bottom line is depressing in the extreme. Lets lt our sights higher than this.Actually, the more I think about it, the more offensive jump the queue  is as a description of a reciprocal right of free movement. Really disgraceful. Businesses in sectors which rely on low-skilled workers, such as hospitality, manufacturing and the care industry, have raised concerns about the impact of restrictions on labour. CBI director-general Carolyn Fairbairn said firms needed time to adapt to the seismic sht in the immigration system. And NHS recruiters fear the new system could cut off the supply of overseas nurses and carers. Federation of Small Businessesnational chairman Mike Cherry said: One in five small employers rely on staff from the EU. More than one in three say finding the right staff is currently holding back growth.If theyre lumbered with complex paperwork and a surcharge to bring in EU staff post- Brexit , that will cause a signicant drag on the billions they contribute to the economy each year.Danny Mortimer, NHS Employers chief executive, warned the planned changes could cut off the supply of nurses.  We know we need to increase the number of UK trained health professionals, especially nurses, he said. The recommendations on salary thresholds and having no need for a so called lower skilled, lower wage, route into the UK would cut off the supply of nurses from overseas and there would be no mechanism for employing people into care worker roles. It would be completely unacceptable to allow vital social care services to close under the strain of not having the people required to provide the necessary care. Downing Street defended the plans. Theresa Mays Cabinet has signed off a -page draft Brexit deal with Brussels - and it has enraged Tories. Here are some of the reasons why:The transition period can be extended - and we dont know how long for Goods face being checked between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK We need the EUs permission to quit the backstop European courts will still have a big hold on the UKFOR THE FULL GUIDE CLICK HEREAsked whether Mrs May regarded EU nationals currently working in the NHS and other public services as having jumped the queue , the PMs official spokesman said: We have always been clear of the important contribution which EU citizens make to our economy and to public services.The point the Prime Minister is making is that we wish to have a global system where peoples skills are the basis on which they are able to work in the UK. At the moment, we have two systems in place - one for people coming to the UK from outside the EU and one for people coming out under the rules of free movement. Its a fact that people coming under the system of free movement dont need a visa and those from outside the EU do. The spokesman said an immigration white paper setting out the proposed new system was due to be published shortly.

title: leeds trinity university lecturers told
story: NewsLeeds Trinity University lecturers told not to use frightening capital lettersTeachers are also being warned not to use the word dont and to write in a warm tone, according to reportsShareCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsThe advice is reportedly being given at Leeds Trinity Universitys school of journalism "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLecturers at Leeds Trinity University are being told not to use capital letters when setting assignments, according to reports. Staff at the universitys school of journalism have reportedly been warned writing words capped up could frighten the students into failure. Teachers are also reportedly being told to avoid the use of the word dont and negative instructions. A memo reportedly says lack of clarity when explaining tasks can lead to anxiety, adding that staff should also avoid the use of capitals. Lecturers are instead being told they should write in a warm and helpful tone. According to The Express, a memo says: Despite our best attempts to explain assessment tasks, any lack of clarity can generate anxiety and even discourage students from attempting the assessment at all. The memo says to avoid the overuse of do, and, especially, DONT. One staff member reportedly said they used upper case letters for emphasis. But according to reports, the university said its guidance was based on best practice from the latest teaching research. A tweet posted by the university today said it hadnt banned capital letters, but a statement said it is best practice not to write in all capital letters. Professor Margaret A House OBE, Vice-Chancellor at Leeds Trinity University, told .â€œAt Leeds Trinity University we support our students to be the very best they can be. Weâ€™re proud to offer a personal and inclusive university experience that gives every student the support to realise their potential.â€œWe follow national best practice teaching guidelines and the memo cited in the press is guidance from a course leader to academic staff, sharing best practice from the latest teaching research to inform their teaching.For every assignment, academic staff have an â€˜unpackingâ€™ session with students so the students are clear on what is expected. The majority of universities do this. It is also about good communication and consistent style. For example, it is best practice not to write in all capital letters regardless of the sector. â€œWe are absolutely committed to enhancing and enriching the student learning experience at Leeds Trinity, where staff and students are a name not a number.We support students to achieve their full potential, and we are proud that this is reflected in the Universityâ€™s employability statistics with % of our graduates in employment or further study within six months of graduation, and also in our very successful alumni community.â€  Last month,reported that sign language clapping is being encouraged over regular clapping at The University of Manchesters student union to avoid triggering anxiety. The University of Manchester Students Union passed the resolution to encourage the British Sign Language version at student union events at the first Senate session of the academic year on September , according to student newspaper the Mancunion. It was argued that the loud noise of traditional clapping and whooping pose an issue to students with anxiety or sensory issues. BSL clapping â€“ or, jazz hands â€“ would be a more inclusive form of expression, the paper said.

story: NewsMeghan Markle and mum Doria to be weighed after Christmas dinner with the QueenMeghan could reportedly take part in a fun Sandringham tradition harking back to King Edward VIIShareCommentsByNicola OakleyHead of Audience:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsMeghan and her mum will be joining in the royal traditions this Christmas "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle will be spending her first Christmas as a member of the royal family this year after tying the knot with Prince Harry in May. The Duchess of Sussex will join the Queen and the rest of the royals at Sandringham, their Norfolk estate. Her Majesty has reportedly also invited Meghans mum, Doria Ragland, along to enjoy the festivities an honour rarely extended to people outside the immediate royal family. Meghan and her mum will have to get used to the royal way of doing things - like opening their presents on Christmas Eve - including one tradition thats particularly bizarre. Royal expert and editor of Majesty magazine, Ingrid Seward, claims each member of the family are weighed before and after dinner.  Seward told Grazia that the Queen ensures guests weigh themselves on a pair of antique scales in a tradition harking back to King Edward VII. Edward wanted to ensure his guests were fed well and any visitors to Sandringham were required to sit on the device and be weighed upon arrival and departure to seethey had put on pounds during their stay. If the royals Christmas food is anything like that of the average Brit, everyone will be putting on a few pounds.  Seward also spoke of how unusual it was for the Queen to extend an invitation to a family member of an in-law. â€œIt is unusual for an outsider to be invited, but the royal family does change, she told Grazia. â€œIâ€™m sure the royals will do everything in their power to make Doria feel at home.â€™â€ The royal family usually spends both Christmas and New Year at Sandringham House and have done so since , when Windsor Castle was being rewired causing the royals to relocate.  On Christmas Eve, the family lay out their gts to each other on trestle tables and exchange them at teatime.Presents are usually cheap and fun. Last year, Meghan reportedly gave the Queen a singing hamster which went down well with the Corgis.Prince Harry allegedly once gave his grandmother a shower cap which said aint le a bitch on the front.On Christmas Day the family attends morning service at St Mary Magdalene church, which dates back to the th century.  Crowds usually gather on the route to catch a glimpse of the family as they head into the church.Royals then head back to Sandringham for Christmas lunch - along with the weigh-in tradition - and to watch the Queens speech.The Queen gives Christmas presents to all members of The Royal Household and pays for  Christmas puddings to be distributed to workers throughout the palaces, Court Post Office and palace police.

title: toddlers final hours after skin
story: NewsToddlers final hours after skin began peeling off like she had been on fireKhadijah Arafs brothers know "she is in heaven" and point to the sky when the family talk about her following her tragic death - says dad Sunny who took out a billboard in Birmingham to thank medicsShareCommentsByAmber Hicks:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video brave-dad-posting-final-photo-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA grieving father has described the moment his daughters skin began peeling off like she had been on fire before her heart stopped twice and she died at his side.Daddys girl Khadijah Araf was just weeks away from celebrating her third birthday when tragedy struck and she suffered fatal septic shock. Just hours earlier, dad Sunny had been putting Khadijah in her car seat when the flesh on her hands and legs started blistering.By the time they got to hospital, the blisters had spread all over her body.  She was rushed straight into theatre and doctors started pumping her with fluids and antibiotics, while Sunny and we Nida sat in a room desperately waiting for updates.During the agonising wait, doctors came in and said Khadijahs heart had stopped but they had managed to restart it. However, they warned she did not have long to live. Thatâ€™s when we started phoning family to come, Sunny said. Tragically Khadijahs condition rapidly deteriorated and despite doctors attempts to resuscitate her, she died with her parents by her side. The day before, they had spent a lovely day out at a park, but Khadijah didnt seem well so they took her to hospital.The staff thought it was a virus and sent her home, Sunny added. However, the next day we Nida was convinced something was seriously wrong with her daughter and they knew they needed to take her back.Sunny and Nida, who have three sons aged eight, five and three, are still coming to terms with the sudden death of Khadijah, who was also born with a complex heart condition. Just last month, Sunny stood for hours next to a billboard in Birmingham showing the final photo of him and Khadijah as a thank you to Birmingham Childrens Hospital and the care they gave her. People reacted by calling Sunny an inspiration and a brave man with a good heart.  Paying tribute to Khadijah, Sunny said: The boys know their sister is in heaven. Even our youngest points to the sky and says up when we talk about her. Khadijah was a little busy body, very talkative and lively. She loved babies, always wanted to be mum when she was playing. And she was very strong and resilient because she went through so much. She had a fighting spirit few adults have. Now, the Erdington dad has gone a step further - by taking aid out to Syrian refugees in Lebanon.  Its been six months since we lost our daughter Khadijah and, although the pain will never go away, its moments like this that are part of the healing process, he told Birmingham Live. When she passed away, we had lots planned like charity dinners, appeals and aid trips and I said to my we shall we cancel everything  And she said no you have to carry on, these people need your help. So thats what weve done. Sunny runs ISA Foundation, a charity that delivers aid where its most needed. He and his team helped , people in Lebanon earlier this month, mostly thanks to donations that have come in via Green Lane Mosque in Birmingham.  This is the seventh time weve been out there to support the Syrian refugees displaced from their country, said Sunny, a former policeman who runs a security and logistics firm. Theyre still staying in makesht shelters no-one expected them to be there for three to four years. Now that winter is coming, we went to support them with donations of food, winter clothing and fuel for their heaters to help them survive the harsh winter. He added: The temperatures get very low, our winter is nothing compared to there. And the children are just in slippers and flipflops. They dont even have shoes and socks and theyre living in mud.  Our dogs live in better conditions in their kennels here than those refugees do. The area where they visited is hard to reach so the last time these refugees received aid was when the ISA Foundation visited them last year. Its heartbreaking, really emotional, said Sunny. I have to wear sunglasses otherwise theyll see me crying all the time.  Theres a little girl who was born in the camp and has Downs syndrome. Shes walking now and she came running over to me. She looks a bit like Khadijah. Her parents dont know about her condition and what lies ahead for them. I spoke to a widow with four kids whose father was shot by a sniper in the war. She says she hasnt the courage to tell them their father has died so she just tells them hes making a long journey. Its so emotional.

The woman, who did not wish to be named, told the Daily Mirror: â€œIâ€™ve never been so low in my whole le. â€œA few months ago I was going to kill myself and my son because I couldnâ€™t deal with it. â€œBut when I go and pick my boy up from school and he smiles at me, it builds me and I think, I canâ€™t do that to him - Iâ€™m not a killer.  â€œIâ€™ve been to the doctor and Iâ€™m on antidepressants and theyâ€™re helping but I feel like Iâ€™m just in a nightmare. â€œEvery month my money comes in and within the week its gone. story: NewsChris Watts jailed for killing we and kids and taking bodies out like trashThe -year-old killer was handed five le sentences without the possibility of parole for murdering we Shanann, , along with their daughters Bella, four, and Celeste, threeShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video moment-judge-sentences-chris-watts-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChris Watts was branded a heartless monster today as the killer was sentenced for the murder of his pregnant we and two daughters. The -year-old killer was handed five le sentences without the possibility of parole for murdering we Shanann, , along with their daughters Bella, four, and Celeste, three. Watts cried and shook in court as he listened to Shananns father, Frank Rzucek, speak about how his pregnant daughter and granddaughters lives were taken by an evil, heartless monster who took their bodies out like the trash. Frank said: God only knows what happened that night but le will never be the same. They had all their lives to live. They were taken by a heartless one, taken by an evil monster the heartless monster. You took them out like trash - you disgust me.  They were loving and caring people. You may have taken their bodies from them, but you have never taken the love they had for me you monster. You heartless monster you have to live with this vision every day of your le. You have no heart or feelings - prison is too good for you. Shananns mother also spoke to the court and addressed Watts, in part saying: Your faithful we trusted you, your daughters trusted you. I have no idea who gave you the right to take their lives, but I know God and his mighty angels were there at that moment to bring them home to paradise. Not only did you take your family of four, you took your own le. I want the world to know our daughter and her children were so loved by us. Watts parents Ronnie and Cindy also made a statament. It read: We are not here to ask for leniency we are not condoning or tolerating the crime that occurred and the pain caused we join in our daughter in law and grandchildrens family in saying this should never have happened. Theyaccept their son has done this they accept their son chose to plead guilty. They appreciate he is given the opportunity to serve this sentence.  It is not enough to make up for what he has done. Cindy Watts continued: This is something we will never get over, we will always mourn the loss of our family. I am still struggling to understand why and how this tragedy occurred. To my son Chris I have known you since the day you were born. You were a good friend, brother, father and son. I have loved you from the beginning and we still love you now. This might be hard for some to understand how I can sit here and tell you we are heartbroken. We cant imagine what could have led us to this day but we love you. As your mother Chris, I have always loved you and still do. I hate what has happened, we are struggling to understand but we will remain faithful as your family. We love you and we forgive you son. The court heard how Shanann was strangled to death, while his young girls were smothered. The court heard how Bella had fought for her le and bit her tongue during the struggle against her father.Imagine the horror in Bellas mind as her father took her last breaths away, a prosecutor said at Mondays sentencing, adding that Bella fought back for her le. Judge Marcelo Kopcow: This is perhaps the most inhumane and vicious crime that I have handled out of the thousands of cases that I have seen. Watts pleaded guilty to nine counts in total - including three counts of first degree murder after deliberation, two counts of first degree murder - a victim under  in a position of trust, one count of first-degree unlawful termination of a pregnancy and three counts of tampering with a deceased human body.  Speaking at a plea hearing where Watts pleaded guilty in exchange to avoid the death penalty, Judicial District Attorney Michael Rourke said: He deserves a le sentence for each and every act on top of each other. It was important that each of those beautul human beings was respected in that sentence. Watts buried his we in a shallow grave and stuffed his dead daughters in oil tanks where he worked, officials previously said. Their bodies were discovered days after the trio were reported missing from their home in Frederick, Colorado. After the trio vanished, Watts made a tearful TV plea to find them. Days later, on August , he was arrested but denied he had killed them.  But things then took a sinister turn and he repeatedly changed his story to police. He claimed that his we had strangled their daughters in revenge after he revealed he was having an affair and wanted to split. He allegedly told detectives that he flew into a rage and strangled Shanann after catching her in the act on a baby monitor screen. But police rejected his story and charged him with three counts of first-degree murder.

title: fans backing can be points in the bag for dundee united
story: There are few managers operating in the Championship right now who know better than Robbie Neilson just how powerful fans can be.As a player, he played more than two thirds of his  plus games title: City countdown to Christmas begins
story: THE countdown to Christmas in Inverness will begin officially on Sunday evening when thousands are expected to take part in the switch-on of the Christmas lights in the city centre.It will begin with a traditional torchlit procession led by Santa and Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael and escorted by mascots including Woody and Buzz Lightyear from Toy Story who will be making their first visit to the event.Families are asked to make their way to Crown Primary School from pm to buy their torches and take their places behind members of the City of Inverness Senior and Youth Pipe Bands who will be competing amongst themselves to see who can be the most outrageously decorated.The procession will set off from the school at .pm and will travel down Stephens Brae to High Street.After arriving there, the children will be invited to help Santa turn on the Christmas lights with a series of boisterous countdowns led by host Nicola McAlley of STV.After each section has twinkled into le, members of the procession will gather outside Inverness Town House where they will get their first glimpse of the colourful lighting scheme which was recently installed during the buildingrsquos refurbishment.After the Christmas and Town House lights have been switched on, Santa and the provost will join families for the traditional Christmas carol service Ding Dong Merrily Old High.It will start at .pm in the Old High Church.Councillor Bet McAllister is a member of the Inverness Events and Festivals Working Group.ldquoThe Christmas lights torchlight procession is one of the most popular events in our Winter Festival programme for the younger members of our community and we are looking forward to creating something really magical for them to enjoy, she said.Monday  Nov  : PM

title: Dozens of drivers nabbed speeding outside schools
story: MORE than  drivers were caught speeding near schools by police during the October holidays.Enforcement was carried out near a number of schools including Holm Primary, Lochardil Primary, Hilton Primary and Cradlehall Primary.During the week of enforcement  drivers were warned for speeding offences, three drivers were issued with conditional offers of a fixed penalty and  drivers were reported to the procurator fiscal ndash of these, three were reported for dangerous driving offences after vehicles were detected travelling at more than twice the speed limit.A -year-old man who was stopped near Hilton Primary on Thursday will also be reported for a number of other offences, including driving while disqualied and without insurance.Sergeant Gus Murray from Police Scotlandrsquos Highland and Islands road policing team said: ldquoIt is disappointing that drivers continue to fail to comply with speed limits around schools and we will continue to carry out enforcement.It followed similar operations in Inverness in August and September.During school term time reduced speed limits nearby are aimed at improving road safety and encouraging children to walk or cycle.Monday  Nov  : PM

title: Dress donations help with baby loss
story: A CHARITY which transforms wedding dresses and occasion dresses into handmade garments for stillborn babies is seeking volunteers in Inverness.Zaagi aims to support grieving families facing the stress and the heartache of bereavement following the loss of a baby to miscarriage, stillbirth or neo-natal death.It was founded three years ago by bereaved Lauder mother Kim Shaw-Walker. Its name means ldquoto be loved and treasured in the language of the Native American Indians in Michigan where she grew up.Its services include handmade garments for baby loss such as nesting blankets and blessing gowns which are donated to hospitals.Volunteers and donations of dresses are now being sought in Inverness where an event will be held tomorrow at the Christian Youth Centre in Bank Street between am and .pm.Susan Simpson, the Highland ambassador for SiMBA ndash another charity which supports bereaved families suffering the loss of a baby through stillbirth or miscarriage ndash said her daughter Eilidh Beth was stillborn at Raigmore Hospital in  and spent the day wrapped in hospital towels.ldquoIf Irsquod only known about an organisation like Zaagi, my mum would not have had the heartache of searching the shops for an outfit for her to wear when we had to say goodbye to her, she said.BBC Alba presenter Magraveiri Rodgers gted her wedding dress to the charity during the filming of a documentary Labour of Love about her own loss. She has since donated gowns from her dress to Raigmore Hospital.Mrs Simpson can be called on  .Monday  Nov  : PM

title: Flights to London are a boon for business
story: BRITISH Airways is to increase the number of flights it operates between Inverness and London Heathrow.The airline said it would operate two dailyservices on weekdays and threeservices at weekends from next summer.From March , the number of weekly British Airways flights between the two cities will increase from  to  over the summer.Fraser Grieve, the Scottish Council for Development and Industryrsquos Highlands and Islands director, said: ldquoItrsquos a fantastic show of confidence in Inverness.ldquoThis move opens up a huge number of additional routes for passengers from the Highlands and it is also fantastic for those wanting to come and visit here.The air link was reinstated in  after years of campaigning.Inglis Lyon, managing director of Highlands and Islands Airports which operates Inverness Airport, said: ldquoLocal businesses will benefit from greater connectivity with London and beyond and it opens up opportunities for visitors to access all that the area has to offer.ldquoThis really is a game changer for Inverness and the Highlands and Islands.The winter programme will see a doubling from seven to services a week, with the airline operating a double-daily schedule from October .Highland Council leader Margaret Davidson welcomed the move. ldquoThe council has long recognised the importance of having regular direct flights into Heathrow and improved air links is a key ask in our city-region deal, she said.ldquoThis news is a vote of confidence in the Highland economy and will be welcomed by business, residents and visitors.Phyllis Stuart, British Airwaysrsquo airport manager in Inverness, said: ldquoWe have been able to increase flights to Inverness because the airport is exempt from air passenger duty.ldquoSince we reintroduced the daily service between Inverness and Heathrow we have seen steady growth in passenger numbers at both ends of the route and this further expansion is testament to the support our partners at Inverness Airport and the people and business community have given us over the past two years.Monday  Nov  : PM

title: Outdoor adveture drive for tourist sector
story: UNLOCKING revenue from the untapped outdoor adventure market was the key theme of the Highland Tourism Conference at The Drumossie Hotel this week.More than  people attendedthe event which was sparked-off by keynote speaker and double gold Olympic medallist sailor and CNN broadcaster Shirley Robertson.The meeting, which comes after The Lonely Planet selected the Highlands and Islands amongst its Best in Travel for  ndash the only Scottish destinations to be included ndash carried a clear message: Give tourists what they are looking for: a spot of adventure in the fresh Highland air.Niche markets like sailing, or whisky and mountain-biking trails were highlighted as strong ideas that could ldquoextend the Scottish welcome and enhance that visitorrsquos inidual experience of the Highlands.Graeme Ambrose, chief executive of Visit Inverness Loch Ness who talked about LochNess , said all were agreed that maximising the potential of the outdoor and adventure markets is fundamental to a more sustainable Highland tourism industry.Other speakers included adventure cyclist Ed Shoote.Monday  Nov  : PM

story: THE deadline to find the arearsquos best young photographers has been extended until the end of the year.The Inverness Courier and Inverness Camera Club ndash which are both celebrating milestone anniversaries ndash have joined forces to launch a photographic competition.Aimed at eight to -year-olds, entrants are asked to submit an image depicting the theme, Inverness Past and Present.The winners will have their work published in the Courier and receive a voucher and framed print of their entry.The competition marks the th anniversary of the Courier while the camera club is celebrating its th anniversary.As part of its celebrations, the club is displaying membersrsquo past images at Eden Court Theatre in Inverness. title: boss mcinnes delighted as reynolds is flying back from injury
story: Dons boss Derek McInnes today confirmed Mark Reynolds is â€œflyingâ€ through his rehabilitation from a long-term knee injury and on course toin January.The -year-old has been sidelined since undergoing surgery in late July on a serious knee injury sustained in a friendly clash against Highland League side Cove Rangers.Defender Reynolds is now running with Pittodrie physios during training sessions, though McInnes insists he will not be ready tofor the congested end to the year where the Reds play nine games in December.However, the long-serving defender, who has racked up  appearances for the Dons over nine seasons, is on schedule toafter the winter break.Reynoldsâ€™will boost the Redsâ€™ centre-back options as, at the moment, Scott McKenna, Mikey Devlin and Andy Considine, who operates primarily at left-back, are the only experienced central defenders available.Aberdeen face a sweat over the fitness of Devlin for the Betfred Cup final against Celtic on December , after he had to pull out of the Scotland squad for the Nations League ties with Albania and Israel having sustained a foot injury training with Alex McLeishâ€™s squad.McInnes said: â€œMark is absolutely flying and is doing terrically well.â€œHe keeps getting the go-ahead from the surgeon and has had that several times over the last wee while at dferent stages so that he can keep pushing on.â€œThey are extremely happy with him.â€œThe one thing with Mark is that he is so determined and committed to doing all the work.â€œRehabilitation from that type of injury isnâ€™t easy. How you come back from that type of injury is normally how much you put into your rehab.â€œMark has given absolutely everything. He is out running, he is out doing the warm-ups with the other players.â€œMark is out running with physios when we are training. It is great to see him with his boots on and getting that step closer.â€œThere might be some set-backs along the way with that type of injury but it is all systems go. Mark has been fantastic and the physios could not be more pleased with him.â€Reynolds limped off just  minutes into the friendly with Cove Rangers. A scan revealed the extent of the damage and he subsequently underwent surgery in Glasgow.That friendly was abandoned as Coveâ€™s Jordon Brown, , suffered a serious head injury in an accidental collision with Dons defender Considine in the second half.An ambulance was called, with spectators asked to leave, and Brown received treatment for more than  minutes.The ex-Aberdeen youngster has gone on to make regular appearances for Cove this season.â€œIf Mark gets close round about January, in the winter break, to coming back then he has done extremely well,â€ said McInnes.â€œIt can be a seven to eight-month injury.â€œConsidering he did it in July, as good as Mark is doing and encouraged as we are, we still have to be careful.â€œIt is a serious injury and we have to treat it that way.â€Reynoldsâ€™ serious knee problem was the first set-back in what would become an injury crisis for Aberdeen in the early throes of this season. At one point, McInnes had eight players out injured.Reynolds and on-loan Watford defender Tommie Hoban, who is recovering from shoulder surgery, are the only two long-term absentees for the Dons now.Aberdeen are to assess the extent of the injury to Devlin that forced him tofrom the Scotland squad.McInnes said: â€œWe did not have our troubles to seek with injuries. It was the worst injury situation since I have been at Aberdeen.â€œWith Mark, he had done all the pre-season work so to then get injured in a pre-season game sticks in the throat a wee bit.â€œBut that is the nature of the game and with injuries you can never foresee when they come.â€œThankfully we have dealt with them as a squad and Mark is dealing with his injury.â€

title: castle gets stateside feel for celebration
story: A historic north-east castle turned red, white and blue to help celebrate a twinning agreement.The American flag was flown from Castle Fraser as part of Stonehaven and the North East Scotland Twinning Groupâ€™s latest partnership.Athens, Alabama, in the United States is set to sign a twinning agreement next year.And Athens celebrated its th anniversary on Saturday, with the north-east sharing in the occasion.A special birthday cake was baked by castle staff, with the Scottish delegation joining in celebrations via video link on Saturday.Ellen Wong, US principal officer to Scotland from the US Consulate-General in Edinburgh also joined in celebrations at Castle Fraser.Before arriving at the th-Century castle she was shown around Stonehaven, including the harbour and Tolbooth Museum.She spoke of an educational exchange programme taking place between the two towns and said she would do everything she can to realise this.Ms Wong has promised toto Stonehaven in the summer to meet the US delegation.Phil Mills-Bishop, co-ordinator for the twinning group, said: â€œModern twinning is much more than just a civic connection with just a plaque in the respective town squares of the twinning towns.â€œTo ensure long-term sustainability it should include educational exchanges, tourist flows, reciprocal sporting events and business opportunities.â€œThis fosters greater understanding between respective communities that is no bad thing in an unstable world.â€Piper Daniel Milne from Robert Gordonâ€™s College Pipe Band helped the US town celebrate by playing happy birthday.A team from Stonehaven is expected to visit Athens in May or June, while an Alabama contingent is due to travel to the north-east in July.Speaking via video link in the United States, Athens mayor Ronnie Marks said: â€œCelebrating our th birthday with our new friends in Scotland is an honour and one of many endeavours we will embark on as we forge this sister city relationship.â€
