title: local charities urge readers to show support for vital change the future campaign
story: Will to Give is a group of  Northern Ireland cherished charities who have come together with one aim - to increase awareness of how important gts in wills are to the causes we all care dearly for.November  -  is Will to Give week, and local charities are asking our readers across Northern Ireland to help Change the Future for the charities you care for by leaving a gt in your willWith this in mind, Will to Give is dedicating this weekto encourage readers across the province to think about making their will and perhaps consider leaving a charitable gt to their favourite cause with their Change the Future campaign.A Will to Give spokesperson said: Every day right here in Northern Ireland lives are transformed thanks to the generosity of gts left in Wills by local people.These gts make a huge contribution to our work and typically fund le-changing research projects and services which can impact on thousands of local lives and change the future for many.Your will tells the people you leave behind, about the person you are. Itrsquos about the people you love and the things you care about. Your will helps pass on your principles and the values that matter to you. A gt in your will can ensure that your most loved charities can continue to make a dference for many years to come.Will to Give member USPCA We believe our success in preventing animal cruelty and the relief of suffering is an enduring tribute to those absent friends who shared our valuesEimear McCooey, Will to Give Chair, agreed: ldquoWe plan for lersquos major milestones births, weddings, anniversaries but most of us shy away from talking about and planning for death - yet it is the one thing that is guaranteed to happen to us all!I strongly believe that talking openly about the future can help ensure we have a better experience when it eventually does happen, and one of the things we can plan for is the legacy we want to leave behind.Making a will is important because it gives you the peace of mind of knowing that your wishes will be respected and the ones you love are looked after, whether that be family, friends or even a well-loved charity. I am leaving a small gt to the charities I care for in my will.Will to Give member the USPCA added its appreciation of the value of legacy gts with Brendan Mullan, Chief Executive, explaining:ldquoThe USPCA was established in  and since then the activities of the USPCA have evolved to meet the ever-changing needs of animals.By deciding to leave us a gt in your will you are helping us protect all animals across Northern Ireland.Legacies are extremely important to the USPCA and without these the charity would not be able to deliver our vital services to animals. We believe our success in preventing animal cruelty and the relief of suffering is an enduring tribute to those absent friends who shared our values.Will to Give added: Anyone can leave a gt in their will. It really doesnrsquot matter what size ndash small or large, every gt is greatly received.It is very easy to leave a gt in yourwill to charity ndash in fact, hundreds of people do it every year in Northern Ireland. We will always advise you to speak with your solicitor to have your will drafted correctly. Your solicitor should be familiar with how to write such a gt into your will.Further informationWill to Give is a charity dedicated to promoting charitable gts in Wills in Northern Ireland. With almost  charity members, representing all sizes and causes, Will to Give is making steady progress in raising awareness of the signicance and positive impact associated with leaving a charitable Will gt.Join Will to Give @WilltoGive on Facebook and Twitter #changethefuture and share with Will to Give what you wish the future to hold for your chosen charity.Email info@willtogive.org for more information or visit Will to Give on their website: www.willtogive.org.

title: meet the ni woman who looks after one of the uk s most iconic bridges
story: As a self-confessed #bridge geek#, Co Down woman Trish Johnson really does have the dream job.For the past two years the -year-old chartered civil engineer has been bridgemaster at one of the UKâ€™s most iconic bridges â€“ the Clton Suspension Bridge in Bristol.Brunels world famous Clton Suspension Bridge opened in .She is responsible for the day-to-day running of the -year-old structure â€“ a busy toll bridge that carries thousands of vehicles across the Avon Gorge each day â€“ and its upkeep and preservation.â€œBridgemaster is quite a historic title,â€ Trish explained. â€œThere are very few bridgemasters in the country, in fact I think I might be the only one. â€œItâ€™s basically looking after all aspects of the Clton Suspension Bridge. Looking after the maintenance of it, the operations of it, all the visitorsâ€™ services, and the staff and all that side of things.â€œAnything that happens on the bridge is my responsibility and itâ€™s my job to make sure it gets sorted out.â€Trish Johnson making safety checks on the bridge.Born in Belfast, Trish grew up in Banbridge, attended St Maryâ€™s Primary School and then Banbridge Academy where she completed her A Levels before going on to study engineering at the University of Salford, Manchester.After graduating, she says she â€œsort of fell intoâ€ bridge engineering and maintenance â€“ an industry she has remained in for more than  years.Trish, who is better known to family and friends in Northern Ireland as Patricia, has been bridgemaster at Clton for the past two years. But previously she was in charge of maintenance at the Severn Bridge and the Second Severn Crossingand before that looked after bridges and highways across Wiltshire and Avon.She is the first woman to take on the role of bridgemaster at Clton, but says she isnâ€™t tempted to change her title to bridgemistress.An aerial view of the Clton Suspension Bridge, which spans the Avon Gorge and the River Avon.â€œIt is a historic title so it would be unfair to try to change it. Iâ€™m happy with bridgemaster, so I wouldnâ€™t want to try to change the course of history!â€Trish manages a team of  people including bridge attendants, visitor centre staff, maintenance workers and administration staff, as well as dozens of volunteers who help out with ious projects.â€œI really enjoy it. Itâ€™s fantastic,â€ she said. â€œIt is a real honour to be looking after such a historic asset. Iâ€™ve been in Bristol  or  years now â€“ a long time since I left Northern Ireland â€“ and the bridge has always been a part of my tours when family have been over, so itâ€™s amazing that Iâ€™m actually looking after it now. and Santa getting ready for the Twilight Market in Portadown."   and Santa getting ready for the Twilight Market in Portadown." The bridge itself is over  years old. It is one of the icons of Bristol. We get half a million visitors here every year, so it is my responsibility to make sure the bridge is well maintained, safe to use and that it is there for a long time to come.â€œIt is a historic Grade  listed structure and there are not many historic Grade  listed structures that are still used as a transport asset. We still have four million vehicles cross the bridge every year, so it is a working asset as well as a historical and visitor attraction, so there is a lot to the job and it definitely keeps me busy.â€The married mum-of-two admits to being slightly obsessed with bridges, and once even booked a weekend trip to Copenhagen just so she could visit the Ã–resund Bridge which runs between Denmark and Sweden.Her husband Rob, who works in finance, may not share her passion for bridges, but it seems heâ€™s seen more than his fair share over the years.â€œWhen we go on holidays he ends up getting trailed round every bridge,â€ Trish smiled. â€œHeâ€™s getting used to the bridges by now!â€Neither of Trishâ€™s children share her love of engineering either. Her daughter Fiona, , works in marketing, while son Thomas, , is studying economics at university.She says she tried to get them into engineering, without success. But sheâ€™s adamant that more needs to be done in the UK in general to encourage young people, particularly girls, to get into science, technology, engineering and mathssubjects.â€œI think the UK has got the lowest percentage of female engineers in Europe and thatâ€™s a sad situation. Weâ€™ve probably got about % or less female engineers across the UK, so it is really important that we increase the number of women in engineering. â€œWe need to increase the number of people with engineering skills full stop, but we need to tap in to that whole area of getting girls engaged and interested in engineering,â€ she continued.â€œMaths was my big thing. I am one of these geeks really. The problem solving side of things is what I really liked, and still do really, and engineering is perfect for that. There is always a problem youâ€™ve got to sort out, and thatâ€™s what gets me out of bed in the morning.â€œI have done it for  years and I have had a whale of a time and really enjoyed it. Itâ€™s not just about getting your hands dirty and the mud and concrete and that side of things, there is so much more to it than that and thatâ€™s what we have to try to get across to the youngsters of today.â€Trish, whose father Tommy Fee is well known in the Banbridge area for having run  fitness classes at the local college for more than four decades, has made her le in Bristol and says she has no plans at present tohome to Northern Ireland.â€œI get drawn back every now and then. I go back to see family and friends. But my husband and kids are here so I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ll be moving home just yet, but who knows what weâ€™ll do when we retire.â€THE FACTSâ€¢ The Clton Suspension Bridge opened in . It is a private bridge run by a trust.â€¢ The  feet long, ,-tonne structure spans the Avon Gorge and River Avon between Clton in Bristol and Leigh Woods in North Somerset.â€¢ The deck of the Grade  listed structure sits  feet above the river.â€¢ Its designer, Isambard Kingdom Brunel, was just  when he was appointed project engineer. â€¢ Brunel died in  â€“ five years before the bridge he described as â€œmy first loveâ€ officially opened.â€¢ Today the bridge serves as a crossing for more than four million vehicles every year.â€¢ Vehicle drivers have to pay a Â£ toll to cross the bridge, and the money goes towards the upkeep of the historic structure.â€¢ Trish Johnson, the first female bridgemaster, took over the role in October .

title: the search is on for community heroes names
story: Nominations are now open for the third annual Live Here Love Here Community Awards and organisers are calling on people in the Armagh, Banbridge and Craigavon area to make sure to nominate their #Community Heroes# - those who give up their time to keep our communities cleaner, greener and safer.The awards, held at Belfast City Hall on February  , are organised by charity Keep Northern Ireland Beautul to celebrate and recognise the work of groups and iniduals who instil pride in communities across Northern Ireland through environmental action such as clean ups, green ups and spruce ups.Local volunteers keep Banbridge communities cleaner, greener and safer.Last year, Â£m was spent cleaning the streets of Northern Ireland, which is a massive burden on the public purse. Live Here Love Here, along with the help of a dedicated team of volunteers, run a number of clean up projects throughout the year. The Big Spring Clean, Northern Irelandâ€™s largest anti-litter campaign, was supported by , volunteers in  and as a result, removed a massive  tonnes of litter across Northern Ireland.Jodie-Ann McAneaney, Live Here Love Here Manager said: â€œLast year we received  nominations across Northern Ireland, with volunteers as young as five years old being celebrated. Given the amount of volunteers we had participating in our clean ups this year, we hope to see even more nominations for . â€œIf you know anyone who is dedicated to keeping our environment healthy, it can be anything from reducing litter or dog fouling, improving the quality of their local environment or even creating a shared community space â€“ then make sure you nominate them and give them the recognition they deserve!â€Jodie continued: â€œItâ€™s truly heart-warming to see the huge effort being made across local communities to create and maintain a better place for everyone to live.Â  â€œWeâ€™re looking forward to celebrating our community heroes at the awards ceremony in February. The recognition is our way of thanking them, with their support we hope to encourage more people to get involved and Live Here Love Here.â€With  categories to apply for there is something for everyone. Whether your nominee is a dedicated litter hero, a tourism booster or a neighbourhood champion, now is your chance to say thank you.Entry is free and easy, simply download an application pack from www.liveherelovehere.org, fill out the nomination form and send it to karina.magee@keepnorthernirelandbeautul.org beforeÂ  noon on January  .The awards will take place on Tuesday, February   at Belfast City Hall, hosted by Lesser Spotted Journeys Ulster presenter, Joe Mahon.Live Here Love Here is an inspiring partnership between the Department of Agriculture Environment and Rural Affairs Choice Housing Northern Ireland Housing Executive Coca-Cola McDonaldâ€™s and ten local councils, working alongside Keep Northern Ireland Beautul.To learn more about the categories and awards please visit www.liveherelovehere.org. with Melanie Christie Boyle, Chief Executive of Ballymena Business Centre, who provided Helen with expert advice and help with developing a business plan in order to help turn her business idea into a reality"   with Melanie Christie Boyle, Chief Executive of Ballymena Business Centre, who provided Helen with expert advice and help with developing a business plan in order to help turn her business idea into a reality"  Local mum hails Go For It programme after she achieves le goal of opening her own business Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BANB | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BANB | Article Teaser"

Ireland AwardsSearchGoHome# News# Northern IrelandReview: Rustioni leads orchestra as it performs a trio of greats" title"Under the direction of Rustioni, this was a stately and measured performance of this truly "great" symphony, which finally burst into le in the finale " width"" ""  " title"Under the direction of Rustioni, this was a stately and measured performance of this truly "great" symphony, which finally burst into le in the finale " width"" ""  Under the direction of Rustioni, this was a stately and measured performance of this truly "great" symphony, which finally burst into le in the finale By Alf McCrearyNovember   CommentsReview: Rustioni leads orchestra as it performs a trio of greatsBelfastThe Ulster Orchestra, under the baton of the distinguished young conductor Daniele Rustioni, continued its successful - season with music by Busoni, Mozart and Schubert in a well-filled Ulster Hall.https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland review-rustioni-leads-orchestra-as-it-performs-a-trio-of-greats-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph migration_catalog article.ece  AUTOCROP h cello.jpgEmailThe Ulster Orchestra, under the baton of the distinguished young conductor Daniele Rustioni, continued its successful - season with music by Busoni, Mozart and Schubert in a well-filled Ulster Hall..pushThe overture Lustspiel by Ferruccio Busoni set the tone for the evening with its exuberant tunefulness, but the centre piece was Mozarts Violin Concerto No , played by the highly talented Francesca Dego, who happens to be the partner of Daniele Rustioni. Their joint interpretation captured the essence of yet another Mozart masterpiece, with the soloist giving a most sensitive performance of the blissful Adagio, which is one of those classical pieces most people recognize, but are sometimes not sure where it comes from.The second half was taken up by Schuberts Ninth Symphony, known as "The Great", which the Ulster Orchestra already performed this year at the end of its lunchtime series in early summer.Under the direction of Rustioni, this was a stately and measured performance of this truly "great" symphony, which finally burst into le in the finale.Schubert was never a composer to waste a good tune and he repeated the main theme all the way to its triumphant climax, to sustained and deserved applause.The Ulster Orchestra is looking for a new principal conductor, and Maestro Rustioni, on his third visit to Belfast, has certainly made his mark.

story: Plans for new a greenway that will facilitate a shared cycling and walking area will go on public display next week in Hollybush Primary School and Muff Community Hall.The emerging design proposals for the planned cycling and walking route that will link Derry to Muff go on display on  and  November. title: nie called review deal customers residents street derry wait nine hours power restored
story: Concerns have been raised after residents of a street in Derry waited nine hours to have power restored to their homes after an underground cable was damaged.The incident happened at the Paddock Lane area in Ballyarnett at pm on Friday, which resulted in a number of homes experiencing a power loss.However, concerns have now been raised that it took NIE nine hours to restore power, given that many of those who live in the area are elderly.Commenting, the independent councillor for the area, Warren Robinson, said that while he understands that certain circumstances could delay power being restored, he was nonetheless concerned at how the issue was handled by NIE.â€œI was made aware of the problem after being contacted by some residents who were affected. â€œConcerns were raised in particular because this area houses a large proportion of elderly residents. â€œI immediately contacted NIE and was informed that a third party contractor had damaged a cable in the area and was told that a repair team were on site but NIE could not give me an estimate for when the fault would be repaired.â€Cllr Robinson added: â€œI understand that sometimes circumstances may mean there is a delay in having repairs carried out but electricity was off in this area for ten hours and my concern would be that elderly residents were left with no information and no offers of help from NIE.â€â€œNIE do have a duty of care to these customers, I believe they have a particular duty of care to our elderly neighbours. googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refreshâ€œNIE need to tell us why it took ten hours for the repair to be carried out. They also need to put measures in place wherebythere is a delay that this is immediately communicated to the affected residents.â€Safety Responding, a spokesperson for NIE said that the efforts of engineers had been hampered by â€˜adverse weather conditionsâ€™, adding that it had been dficult to provide customers with an exact time for when the issue would be resolved due to â€˜complexityâ€™ of the problem.â€œNIE Networks received reports of a fault at Paddock Lane at approximately pm on Friday, November ,â€ a spokesperson said. â€œAn underground electricity cable had been accidentally damaged by a third-party contractor resulting in a small number of customers experiencing loss of electricity supply. â€œThe damaged cable required isolation for safety reasons before engineers could begin to carry out repairs. The spokesperson continued: â€œWe do endeavour to provide our customers with information where possible, however, it was dficult to provide an exact time for restoration on this occasion due to the unforeseen nature and complexity of the fault, as well as the safety required to undertake the repairs. â€œThis was further compounded by our engineers operating in adverse weather conditions. Following excavation work, repairs were carried out to the damaged cable with supply to all affected customers restored by .pm on Friday.â€

title: us investors told north west ireland gateway uk eu markets
story: Potential American investors were told last week that the North West is perfectly placed for an investment hub for business and global companies seeking to establish a gateway to both the UK and EU markets. A number of focused engagements with industry specialists, FDI executives and venture capitalists took place throughout the week in both Philadelphia and Boston as part of the Trade and Investment mission led jointly by Donegal County Council and Derry City and Strabane District Council, presenting the compelling investment proposition that the Northwest City Region has to offer.Potential investors heard from leading global company DuPont, which has a longstanding commitment to the region, taking advantage of the unique combination of benefits that the Northwest region has to offer including an accessible, connected and business friendly gateway region with a compelling vision for greater international impact.Investors learned that companies and businesses are attracted by a talented and educated workforce, the value balance, the superb quality of le and the supportive business environment. Cathaoirleach of Donegal County Council, Cllr Seamus ODomhnaill, who led the delegation along with Cllr John Boyle Mayor of Derry City and Strabane District Council, believes that these types of engagements are essentialwe are to raise the profile of the region as an investment location. â€œHaving these key influencers and potential investors in a room focusing on the northwest region and sharing with them our vision and ambition as well as the practical supports and assistance available to businesses in the region is vital,â€ he stressed. â€œThere is no better way to build meaningful connections and relationships than face to face engagements.â€Mayor John Boyle believes that: â€œThe strength of the region is underpinned by the strong collaborative approach which sees industry, government at both central and local level, and further and higher education institutions from both sides of the border working together to fuel further economic growth and prosperity. This is something that investors value greatly in terms of facilitating ease of access to supports in the region.â€ Local businesses from a range of sectors across both Council areas also participated in the mission meeting with potential clients and business partners with a view to increasing sales and expanding their businesses. Derry based Bridie Mullin Irish Linen Ltd. participated in the mission and brought her eponymous label of handcrafted quality Irish line to Boston in an effort to tap into the US market.Bridie explains that the trade visit was an opportunity to build on her own research, and to visit stores and meet with potential clients gaining a deeper understanding of what exactly the customer is looking for. It also allowed her to get an insight into the potential costs associated with exporting and logistics assisting in finalising price points for trading.googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refreshThe trade and investment mission also involved engagement with educational institutions with a memorandum of understanding being signed by the North West Regional College and Philadelphia Community College and the State of Pennsylvania during the mission that sees the consolidation of relationships developed over the last two years.Samantha Traynor, Vice Principal of the North West Regional College, who also participated in the Trade and Investment Mission, explained: â€œThe MoU represents the first step in building and consolidating a partnership through education and training with a specic focus on sharing best practice in Work Based Learning to include Traineeships, Apprenticeships including Higher Level Apprenticeships and also the continued professional development of our respective professionals in our workforce.â€The week also saw the announcement by both Councils of an exciting research project with Hard Graduate School of Design, exploring how the cross-border northwest city region can be shaped in light of the economic, political and social realities of Brexit. This project is being led by Assistant Professor Gareth Doherty in Hard GSD, who is originally from Donegal. Reaching out to the diaspora was also a key objective of the mission and this manested in events in both Philadelphia and Boston, where members of the diaspora from across the region attended and shared with the delegation the opportunities and challenges faced by the diaspora and their commitment to continue to engage in a way that is meaningful and mutually beneficial. The Cathaoirleach of Donegal County Council also had the honour of accepting on behalf of Donegal Hospice a cheque of , raised by the Donegal community in Philadelphia.Speaking after the trip, Chief Executive of Donegal County Council, Seamus Neely, said: â€œThis Trade and Investment Mission is part of the ongoing positive work being done by both Councils. We are committed to continuing with the positive work we are doing to drive forward our economy and to maximise the opportunities we have as a cross border gateway to both the UK and EU markets. â€œWe have longstanding connections with Philadelphia and Massachusetts and these connections transcend economic, cultural and political linkages. The Golden Bridges conference has provided the Northwest region with an important  in the Massachusetts region allowing us to reach out, connect with and form meaningful relationships and collaborations with stakeholders in ious sectors that have been instrumental in progressing growth and prosperity in the region.â€Reflecting on the visit, Chief Executive of Derry City and Strabane District Council, John Kelpie, said: â€œIt takes time to make connections, develop relationships and build trust. Our ongoing positive engagement with Massachusetts has to date resulted in a number of exciting developments including the investment and success stories around One Source Virtual and Metaverse. â€œResults such as these are part of our key objectives in terms of strengthening the profile of the City Region as outlined in our Strategic Growth Plan and are evidence that our direct approach of travelling to the US, making those connections and building rapport, really works.â€Pictured at the launch of the new research project led by Hard GSD exploring how the northwest region can be shaped post brexit are Cathaoirleach of Donegal County Council Cllr. Seamus ODomhnaill and Mayor of Derry City and Strabane District Council Cllr. John Boyle, Chief Executives of both Councils Seamus Neely and John Kelpie with Assistant Professor Gareth Doherty and Professor Niall Kirkwood from Hard GSD and with representatives from the Planning Services in both Councils, ICLRD, Letterkenny Institute of Technology and members of the Hard GSD team.
